explaination: There is still currently no cure, and this has not been medically verified as a viable treatment.

claim: COVID-19 stands for “Chinese Originated Viral Infectious Disease.”
explaination: The CDC explains the origin of the virus's name, which has nothing to do with China.

claim: NY Governor Andrew Cuomo did not reject buying 16,000 ventilators in 2015.
explaination: The report referred to did not actually make any recommendations for buying ventilators.

claim: Sophie Trudeau is sharing her COVID-19 experience.
explaination: Video is of a woman from London and not Sophie Trudeau.

claim: A positive COVID-19 patient recently met Narendra Modi.
explaination: A 2018 picture is being shared with a false narrative.

claim: A line of coffins suggesting they are from Italy currently.
explaination: Old image of 2013 of migrants dying in a shipwreck shared as recent.

claim: Cow urine is helpful to fight coronavirus.
explaination: No scientific evidence backs the use of cow urine to tackle viruses.

claim: Sick COVID-19 patients at the airport runway in Senegal.
explaination: Video is old and not from Italy. It actually shows mock drill carried out on 28 November 2019 at Blaise Diagne Airport in Dakar, the capital of Senegal. It has nothing to do with coronavirus.

claim: Image claims that dead bodies from Italy are kept in a room.
explaination: The image is from a Cairo Mosque which was turned into a makeshift morgue in 2013.

claim: Consuming alcoholic beverages may help reduce the risk of infection by the novel coronavirus.
explaination: Drinking alcohol does not protect you from coronavirus infection, according to WHO.

claim: US Homeland Security mobilizing National Guard to combat coronavirus.
explaination: National Guard refuted claims.

claim: Coronavirus cases linked to 5G rollout.
explaination: Overlaps in the map between 5G and cases can be explained by population density.

claim: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
explaination: Old photo from African migrants who died from shipwreck in 2013.

claim: Seeing the rise of novel coronavirus in India, the WHO has recommended the government of India lockdown the country from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
explaination: We reached out to one of the representatives in India, who rubbished the claim and clarified that WHO has not made any such recommendation.

claim: Doctors are giving out “rescue packs” for people with pre-existing respiratory conditions.
explaination: There is no evidence that doctors in Ireland are giving out packs containing steroids and antibiotics to people with pre-existing respiratory conditions, such as asthma or COPD. On the contrary, doctors have advised that such a move would not be safe, given the different needs that each patient would have.

claim: “If you are in Las Vegas and you get a knock on your door from NV Power, 2020 Census or CVD-19 testers, do not open your door. They are robbing people at gunpoint.”
explaination: Las Vegas police said they have received no such reports. Similar rumors are being spread around the country.

claim: Fill out a 2020 U.S. Census form to receive an economic stimulus payment.
explaination: U.S. government relief payments for coronavirus relief will be determined by tax returns, not census information.

claim: A photo circulating on Facebook in Nigeria appears to show President Muhammadu Buhari shaking hands with the nation’s Code of Conduct Bureau Chairman Mohammed Isa while both men are wearing face masks — seemingly against precautions during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The image was doctored using an old photo, taken long before the pandemic.

claim: Quotes Joe Biden as saying “people who have never died before are now dying from coronavirus.”
explaination: The quote was first misattributed to President Donald Trump. Joe Biden didn't say it either.

claim: Russia unleashed more than 500 lions on its streets to ensure that people are staying indoors during this pandemic outbreak.
explaination: Russian President Vladimir Putin hasn’t resorted to releasing lions in order to keep people inside during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: A purported warning from Australian hospitals has been shared thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook that using petrol pumps can enable the spread of the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; Australia’s Department of Health said it did not issue the purported advisory; scientists say the virus is unlikely to survive on petrol pumps outside as sunlight and lack of moisture generally kill it; motorists are advised to regularly wash their hands to avoid infection.

claim: Biden campaign claims a top CDC official was “silenced.”
explaination: Messonnier’s remarks on Feb. 25 may have caught the attention of Wall Street and caused angst in the White House. But we cannot find evidence of her being immediately silenced, as Klain claims in the video.

claim: Denmark passed from 200 new cases of COVID-19 in one day to only 26 cases.
explaination: These numbers are not in line with the national authorities, it was never reported 200 or 26 news cases in one day in Denmark. On March 19, there were 75 new cases in the country.

claim: The quarantine in Italy showed more clean waters in Venice with fish and a dolphin.
explaination: It is not true, the image of a dolphin was taken in another Italian city, Cagliari, in the Sardinia island, and not in Venice. It was not due to the quarantine.

claim: Muammar Gaddafi predicted the current coronavirus pandemic, and warned it would be created by the same people who would then sell  the “antidotes.”
explaination: In a speech to the UN General Assembly in 2009, the late Libyan leader did speculate about the creation of viruses and express his concern about the sale of vaccines. But he did not say the quote attributed to him, and he did not "predict" coronavirus.

claim: A post shared thousands of times on Facebook lists companies whose chief executive officers have allegedly stepped down during the novel coronavirus crisis.
explaination: some of the 19 CEOs remain in their positions, while the announcements that others were leaving came before the virus emerged in late 2019.

claim: A video from a British broadcaster shows Italian coronavirus victims got taken down.
explaination: The report is still available on Sky News and was not removed.

claim: Italy’s president was caught on camera crying over and regretting country’s coronavirus response.
explaination: The man in the video is not even Italy's president. It was an older video of Brazil's president at a Thanksgiving service.

claim: Coronavirus life span in a single place is 8 hours, and the Janata Curfew in India is for 14 hours. Thanks to 12 hours of Janata Curfew, the virus will be killed.
explaination: Social Distancing Is Important; But Viral Post Claiming 14-Hr Break Will Kill COVID-19 Is Misleading.

claim: This is a self-check test for coronavirus.
explaination: No, holding your breath for 10 seconds isn't a coronavirus ‘Self-check test. Keeping your throat moist and drinking water every 15 minutes cannot kill coronavirus.

claim: India will go under lockdown from 4/15/20 to 6/15/20.
explaination: Government Of India has clarified that this audio is fake and has no authenticity.

claim: “Gale of the wind” and “Neem Tree” leaves are good medicine to protect from the coronavirus.
explaination: As stated by WHO still there is no official remedy or cure for COVID-19, while some of the traditional methods have symptomatic improvements.

claim: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus.
explaination: Bitter gourd juice cannot cure coronavirus, there is no cure to coronavirus as of this date.

claim: After COVID-19 outbreak in europe Muslims and non-Muslims have come out in the streets shouting praises for Allah and reading Kalma.
explaination: Fact Crescendo found the viral video to be unrelated. The video dates back before the outbreak of COVID-19 in Europe. This is a demonstration march by the citizens in Hamburg, Germany in solidarity with Uyghur Muslims.

claim: Eight COVID-19 patients in Ghana have recovered.
explaination: Please read the full article

claim: There’s definitive proof that chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine, are effective against COVID-19.
explaination: Studies have shown some early promise, but it's not entirely solid to say the treatments work against coronavirus.

claim: Fox News won Pulitzer for coronavirus coverage.
explaination: Claim made on website that is clearly labeled as satire.

claim: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Reddy has claimed that Paracetamol is the only medication for coronavirus.
explaination: It is evident from our findings and Dr. Pandey’s testimony that Paracetamol can help with the coronavirus symptoms but it cannot entirely cure coronavirus. We also found that Paracetamol is not the only medication that can help with coronavirus symptoms as there are many medications.

claim: The United States of America threatened Iraq with coronavirus in 1990.
explaination: According to the AP Archive description, Saddam Hussein said, “If God wills it and we have to run after the enemy, then we will do it.” Also, in AP’s description, we found that Saddam Hussein did not refer to the word ‘Coronavirus’ in the original video.

claim: The spokesman for Chinese Foreign Ministry Zhao Lijian: American CDC admitted that COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as flu. U.S. Army is responsible for the outbreak in Wuhan.
explaination: China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian tweeted and commanded.

claim: An audio clip suggests that the WHO has advised a lockdown.
explaination: A source in WHO confirmed that the organisation has not put out any such information as heard in the viral audio clip.

claim: In an Ethiopian Airlines flight from Italy to Addis Ababa airport this evening, most of the passengers are infected with the virus, and there is no strength except in God.
explaination: The visuals actually pertain to a mock rescue drill that took place at Blaise Diagne Airport near the town of Diass, Senegal. The incident dates back to 28 November 2019 and was a simple simulation aimed at evaluating the capacity to respond to various crises that may arise during airport operations.

claim: Saddam Hussein talked about coronavirus to his cabinet and army in the nineties. He said that America has threatened him to spread this virus if he doesn’t follow their command.
explaination: The viral video is a doctored version of the original video shared by Associated Press in 2015. The audios of both the videos are different not only in terms of their content but voice as well. In the original AP video, Saddam Hussein does not mention the word ‘virus’ or ‘coronavirus.’

claim: Janta curfew in India will help break the chain of transmission.
explaination: The World Health Organisation has maintained that it is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses.

claim: Hospitals are advising people to wear gloves at petrol pumps.
explaination: The hospital named in the message confirmed that it did not issue this advice, and health authorities, including the Chief Medical Officer, said that the public is not being advised to do this.

claim: Gargling with warm salt water can cure from the coronavirus.
explaination: Post claiming gargling with warm salt water can save from coronavirus is fake as per health organizations and experts.

claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill coronavirus.
explaination: An image was shared on WhatsApp claiming that gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar can kill COVID-19. There is no evidence that asserts the claims. The WHO reminds that there is still no medicine or household remedy to treat coronavirus.

claim: President Donald Trump tried to buy a vaccine developed in Germany.
explaination: In an audio a woman said that Trump tried to buy a vaccine that was developed in Germany. However, the german CureVac laboratory denied the allegations on March 16.

claim: A post has been shared tens of thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter which claims that a factory in the Australian city of Melbourne has been hoarding essential supplies including baby formula, toilet paper and hand sanitiser for export to China during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The claim is false; police said the accusation was "false". The company cited in the misleading posts also refuted the claim.

claim: Ugandan landlords have been asked by the government to stop collecting rent as citizens stay home to fight COVID-19.
explaination: A letter allegedly from State House Uganda directing landlords in the country to stop collecting rent as Ugandans stay home to fight COVID-19 is not authentic.

claim: An article claims that a Kenyan died from COVID-19 on 3/20/20.
explaination: An article claiming that a Kenyan had died from COVID-19 on 20 March is false.

claim: An image of coffins showing the victims of COVID-19 in Italy.
explaination: A Facebook post with an image claiming to show the victims of COVID-19 in Italy uses a photo of the coffins of African immigrants who drowned off the coast near Lampedusa in 2013.

claim: U.S. President Donald Trump said in a White House briefing on 3/20/20 that chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, which are often used to treat malaria, have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of COVID-19.
explaination: Chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine is FDA-approved for treating malaria, lupus, and rheumatoid arthritis, but not COVID-19. There is no official cure for the disease as of March 25.

claim: “Wisconsin is the only state where all Republicans voted against protecting its citizens.”
explaination: Wisconsin is indeed the only one of the 50 states where all Republicans voted no. But it’s a bit of an exaggeration to describe that vote as “against protecting its citizens.”

claim: “Fish tank additive may treat coronavirus.”
explaination: Fish-tank cleaners containing chloroquine cannot be substituted for prescription drugs used to treat malaria. The FDA says you should not take chloroquine unless it has been prescribed by a doctor and obtained from a legitimate source.

claim: A post claims that there are no cases of the new coronavirus in Russia.
explaination: In the day that the post was published there were already 147 people infected with COVID-19, according to the national authorities.

claim: Recording of a conversation where one claims to be a friend of the WHO India Director’s brother, Saurabh, who gave him information that India will go into a complete lockdown mode from 4/15/20April to 6/15/20.
explaination: WHO’s official in SEARO confirmed to us that the viral audio on social media is “Fake”.

claim: Bitter gourd juice can cure coronavirus in just two hours.
explaination: PIB India clarified that this viral message is Fake. According to WHO there is no cure medicine discovered or recommended to cure coronavirus.

claim: Using sauna or aiming a hairdryer at one’s nose will kill the coronavirus.
explaination: Expert in infectious diseases said it won't make any impact against coronavirus, and the heat could be damaging if excessive.

claim: Belgium’s health minister banned sex inside or with 3 or more people.
explaination: This is a satirical article.

claim: Bill Gates has access to your DNA and ownership in WHO.
explaination: Gates is not behind testing because each country does that themselves.

claim: Breathing air from a hair dryer or a sauna can prevent or cure COVID-19
explaination: This is false; an expert in coronaviruses said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.

claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.

claim: Popular Cardiologist Devi Shetty talking about symptoms of COVID-19.
explaination: The person in question is a different doctor and not the famous cardiologist.

claim: India asked for restriction of movement.
explaination: The notification is from Malaysia and not India.

claim: You no longer need to have contact with someone to get the coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Donald Trump said about coronavirus, “People are dying who have never died before.”
explaination: Ernest Hemingway said it.

claim: 5G technology caused the coronavirus.
explaination: Historical events were conflated, and did not back up claims with real evidence.

claim: WHO director overstated COVID-19 fatality rate as higher than flu.
explaination: CDC data and doctors said that coronavirus has much higher mortality rate than flu.

claim: Walmart is closing hundreds of its stores.
explaination: This story is several years old, and there has been no recent announcement.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo bought private island to escape coronavirus.
explaination: Ronaldo's management company confirmed it was false.

claim: Trump said “people are dying who have never died before”.
explaination: Searches in databases of the phrase never show up. Other fact checks confirm fabrication.

claim: Obama family flown to private island to escape coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: Website has visible disclaimers saying it is purely satire.

claim: Link takes viewers to application for FEMA assistance in the US.
explaination: Link just takes you to a meme picture.

claim: Sitting in the sunlight will help cure coronavirus.
explaination: The answer to this statement, according to doctors, is more than just true or false. Professor Ramanan Laxminarayan, Director of Centre for Disease Dynamics, Economics and Policy (CDDEP) said that, “We do not know how heat will affect this coronavirus as of yet. Usually, respiratory pathogens disappear in the summer and in the heat, but we have seen many cases in tropical countries too.”

claim: Martial law is imminent in United States.
explaination: U.S. governments are not planning to implement martial law; National Guard is providing aid and support for communities.

claim: A screenshot of a purported internal email disclosing that a bank in the Pakistani city of Rawalpindi was closed after an employee tested positive for the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp.
explaination: The claim is false; the bank said in a statement that “no employee at any” branch had tested positive for COVID-19, and that all branches remained “open and fully operative.”

claim: Posts circulating on social media claim that Ugandan and Kenyan authorities have instructed landlords to stop collecting rent due to the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; the countries have issued public guidance amid the pandemic, but there has been no official communication on rent payments and government officials dismissed the reports.

claim: Gargling salt water can protect against against COVID-19 by washing down the virus into the gut.
explaination: Gargling salt water is not a recommended protective measure against COVID-19, and has been debunked by the World Health Organization.

claim: Tanzanian club spokesman Haji S. Manara was infected with COVID-19 during his tour of The Netherlands.
explaination: Tanzania's Simba Sports Club spokesman Haji S. Manara does not have COVID-19 as claimed, and he was tested after leaving Spain and when he entered the Netherlands.

claim: Fake quote of Senator of the Philippines Francis “Kiko” Pangilinan saying he wants children to be exempted from the lockdown.
explaination: Pangilinan did not say the quote attributed to him. News5 also said the graphic did not come from any of their official social media accounts.

claim: Claim that “there is no” COVID-19 virus.
explaination: The coronavirus is real and infecting thousands of people around the world. As of March 19, COVID-19 had infected more than 191,000 people around the world and resulted in 7,807 deaths.

claim: The federal government is “preparing to mobilize the national guard,” “dispatch them across the US with military” and “announce a nationwide 1 week quarantine for all citizens.”
explaination: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a lockdown. White House officials have repeatedly said it’s not something they’re considering at this time.

claim: For coronavirus cases “in the U.S. 38% of those hospitalized are under 35.”
explaination: The CDC reported that between mid-February and mid-March, 20% of the hospitalizations for coronavirus were for patients age 20-44 and 18% were age 45-54.

claim: “Huge! Results From Breaking Chloroquine Study Show 100% Cure Rate For Patients Infected With The coronavirus.”
explaination: A French study of 20 COVID-19 patients indicates the drug might help treat the coronavirus. But it is no “100% cure.”

claim: Biden claims that Trump eliminated the White House pandemic office.
explaination: One can see the dueling narratives here, neither entirely incorrect. The office — as set up by Obama — was folded into another office. Thus, one could claim the office was eliminated. But the staff slots did not disappear and at least initially the key mission of team remained a priority. So one can also claim nothing changed and thus Biden’s criticism is overstated.

claim: WHO offers free data for coronavirus info.
explaination: Links in post lead to external website, potentially with harmful malware. Post is false, clickbait.

claim: Utility companies Manila Electric Company (Meralco) and Maynilad Water Services Inc are waiving their billings for March 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis.
explaination: The graphic did not come from the official channels of Meralco and Maynilad. The two utility services are only offering an extension for payments, not cancellation of fees.

claim: Indian City Bangalore Municipal Corp. requested people to stay at home and lock down houses as they will be spraying medicine to kill coronavirus.
explaination: Municipal commissioner of the city has no such plans of spraying medicines to kill COVID-19.

claim: The UNHCR said ‘migrants and illegals’ in Malaysia were resisting COVID-19 testing.
explaination: The claim is false; UNHCR officials in Malaysia said the alleged statement is fake and condemned the erroneous claim for stoking “unnecessary fear and distrust”.

claim: Javier Ortega Smith, from VOX, has said that he prefers to be infected by the new coronavirus than to “have homosexualism”.
explaination: This is false; provincial health officials and the mall administrator told AFP that no cases are connected to the mall to date.

claim: Goats in Ajmer, Rajasthan were found to be COVID-19 positive.
explaination: The video is old and unrelated to COVID-19.

claim: Indian cricketer Sachin Tendulkar asked for meat shops to be banned in lieu of COVID-19.
explaination: Claim was falsely attributed to the cricketer.

claim: COVID-19 passengers being disembarked at Senegal airport.
explaination: Video was of a mock drill for dealing with hostage like situations.

claim: In Ecuador, Maritza Frías, former director of the Teófilo Dávila Hospital in Machala, and Mauro Calle, former manager of this health center, concealed official figures of those infected.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Coronavirus phase 4 involves war code.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Australian researchers have found that bananas can help prevent infection of COVID-19.
explaination: We found the post to be False. There is no proof that banana can boost one’s immune system and prevent the disease caused by coronavirus. At present there are no medicines to cure COVID-19.

claim: A video shows Chinese police crackdown on suspected COVID-19 patients.
explaination: We found the video to be False because this is an old video A from Hong Kong showing riot police storm a metro station to crack down on political protesters in the city.

claim: A train carrying vaccines with the inscription “COVID-19.”
explaination: Content seems to be digitally edited, and there is no inscription on that location on such trains.

claim: Evidence Shows The WHO Director-General Overstated COVID-19 Fatality Rate
explaination: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.

claim: Trump Is Promising To Send Americans Checks – Only After Checking People’s Social Media History.
explaination: This is a false tweet, though there have been real suggestions to have a stimulus package.

claim: 5G Technology Believed To Have Caused coronavirus
explaination: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.

claim: “Ministry of Health ITALY released a small video, HOW the virus spreads!!!… BEST VIDEO. Please see ..how innocently it spread. SOAP is the remedy CLEAN/ WASH ur Hands always”
explaination: The viral video is not released by the health ministry of Italy in the wake of coronavirus but it is long-existing on YouTube, we reached the conclusion that the viral claim is ‘Misleading’.

claim: The viral video claims to show the visuals of China police personnel trying to control the patients allegedly suffering from the pandemic.
explaination: The viral video has nothing to do with the coronavirus outbreak and is related to police storming the metro in the wake of Hong Kong protests.

claim: Coronavirus can be cured by sniffing clove and camphor and by drinking water, the virus will go to the stomach and the acid in the stomach will kill the virus.
explaination: Dr. Mohammad Imran, an Ayurveda doctor, said, “It is merely a rumor which has gone viral on social media .There is no scientific evidence which backs the claim that sniffing clove and camphor can cure coronavirus. However, natural camphor and clove does have certain health benefits as it can cure fungus and bacteria”.

claim: As coronavirus outbreak surges, PM Narendra Modi has decided to facilitate fellow countrymen with free masks under the ‘Swacch Bharat’ scheme.
explaination: The government has not announced any such scheme under which it is aimed to provide free masks. The viral webpage may be a part of the decade-old phishing technique or it may be an attempt to collect the data. However, the intent behind creating this webpage is not yet clear but it is crystal clear that the webpage does not belong to Indian govt and might be a venture of some fraudulent organization.

claim: Chinese intelligence officer says the novel coronavirus as a biological weapon invented by China.
explaination: The viral post also claims that the damage caused by the pandemic is being normalized by the Chinese officials. The website which has published the alleged testimony of the said Chinese intelligence officer has published the report with the headline, “CORONA UNMASKED: Chinese Intelligence Officer Reveals True Magnitude of China’s Fake “Coronavirus” Crisis – 包含中文字符版本”. The story published by the Reddit community No Sleep is just a horror story and does not have anything to do with reality. the community itself terms it as a storytelling platform and not a true story publisher.

claim: Countries that are the most affected by the coronavirus are along the same latitude.
explaination: 1. The fact that large countries cannot be represented by a single latitude is conveniently ignored.2. Further, all of the aforementioned cities and countries are not situated along Latitude 40 degrees.

claim: Clorox Already Knew About Coronavirus And Coronavirus Isn’t A New Virus.
explaination: The post claiming that the new coronavirus was known beforehand as Clorox label shows that it kills human coronavirus’ is misleading.

claim: A video of a fire erupting inside a vehicle has been viewed hundreds of times on Facebook, Twitter and on messaging app Line in March 2020 alongside a claim it shows an explosion that was sparked by an alcohol-based disinfectant used during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated in media reports about a car explosion in Saudi Arabia since at least 2015, almost five years before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan in December 2019.

claim: All fruit and vegetable markets in the Indian city of Chennai and across the state of Tamil Nadu have been ordered to close in an effort to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; Chennai’s municipal authority called the social media posts “fake”, and Tamil Nadu’s chief minister said that stores selling “essential items” such as groceries are allowed to operate as normal despite a nationwide lockdown.

claim: Claim that an American soldier was intentionally spreading the novel coronavirus in Wuhan during the seventh CISM Military World Games in October 2019 with a video clip of a man purportedly smearing saliva on the handrail on a train.
explaination: The video is authentic but it was taken in Brussels, Belgium, on March 10, 2020. The man is not an American. According to media reports, the man was arrested by the police on the same day.

claim: As the US government moved to approve a $2 trillion stimulus package to address the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, a short block of text outlining Canada’s alleged response to the outbreak flourished on social media.
explaination: The claims about school closings and economic support are misleading; no province has officially closed schools through the end of the year, only individuals directly impacted by COVID-19 are eligible for financial aid, and mortgage relief is granted by banks on a case by case basis.

claim: The Social Security System (SSS) in the Philippines “approved financial aid worth P20,000 for every member,” to assist those affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The SSS has not announced such financial aid for every member. On its official Facebook page, the SSS denied the claim, saying it was "fake news."

claim: “China is to blame because the culture where people eat bats and snakes and dogs and things like that, these viruses are transmitted from the animal to the people and that’s why China has been the source of a lot of these viruses like SARS, like MERS, the Swine Flu and now the coronavirus.”
explaination: Experts said Cornyn's assertion that Chinese culture is at fault is inaccurate, as the threat of viral transmission from animal to human is not unique to China, and the risk of this kind of spillover is growing globally as humans come into closer contact with animals.

claim: President Donald Trump tweeted, “I ordered the Treasury secretary to send checks to Americans! First however, we will go through your social media history from the last 4 years and search for any post with #NotMyPresident in it. I wouldn’t think of offending you with a check if I’m not your president! #MAGA”
explaination: Americans could receive a $1,000 check as part of an economic stimulus package that isn't yet finalized. Donald Trump didn't tweet that he would vet who gets the checks based on whether they support him.

claim: 2019 coronavirus can live for “up to 3 hours in the air, up to 4 hours on copper, up to 24 hours on cardboard up to 3 days on plastic and stainless steel.”
explaination: Preliminary research indicates that COVID-19 can live for up to three hours in the air, four hours on copper, 24 hours on cardboard and three days on plastic and stainless steel.

claim: Chennai municipal corporation has asked all vegetable and fruit markets to shut down.
explaination: No such order was issued. All vegetable and fruit markets are open in Chennai.

claim: Evidence shows the WHO director-general overstated COVID-19 fatality rate
explaination: All evidence says the WHO director-general was on point. This is a ultra-conservative false spin on what the director-general said, getting many facts and medical numbers wrong.

claim: 5G Technology believed to have caused the coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false, not backed by scientific research, and many dates given to back up the theory are wrong or misleading.

claim: American fast-food chain Hardee’s is advising truckers to walk up to drive-thrus during coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: A spokesperson from CKE Restaurants said the company advises against walking up to drive-thrus for safety reasons.

claim: Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo says bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: The Indian government is distributing free face masks.
explaination: However, the claim is false; the Indian government said there is no such scheme in place and the linked website is not an official government site.

claim: The Australian prime minister is about to announce a national lockdown.
explaination: The claim is misleading; the Australian Prime Minister’s Office refuted the details of the post; Australia's government told its citizens on March 18 not to travel abroad and warned those already overseas to come home but did not order a "lockdown"; AFP found the wording of the misleading posts was identical to Malaysia’s announcement of a nationwide lockdown.

claim: This photo shows a Sri Lankan airline pilot who tested positive for the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; the local health authority told AFP the pilot is not pictured in the photo; the man wrongly identified in the posts denied the claim.

claim: Staff of two Mumbai hotels have COVID-positive cases.
explaination: Both the hotels denied having any such cases.

claim: President Donald Trump announced a vaccine by Roche Diagnostics.
explaination: Roche Diagnostics received FDA approval for testing kits, not a vaccine.

claim: Narendra Modi is giving free masks in India.
explaination: A fake phishing website was set up in the name of Narendra Modi.

claim: Coronavirus patients were being arrested in Punjab, India.
explaination: The video is of a mock drill which is being passed off as real.

claim: Three thousand Ecuadorians are infected with coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Coronavirus will not be covered by private health insurance in Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: The WHO approves anti-malarial drug Chloroquine for COVID-19.
explaination: Fact Crescendo found the details mentioned in the news published by Economic Times to be False. WHO has not declared, approved or recommended anti-malarial drug Chloroquine as a treatment medicine for COVID-19.

claim: Traditional cures and self-checks for the coronavirus.
explaination: Our fact check reveals that there is no scientific evidence to prove that drinking water washes down COVID-19 and gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus. Similarly the self-check breath test for coronavirus is absolutely baseless.

claim: A dog vaccine can be used against coronavirus in people.
explaination: There is still no approved vaccine for coronavirus.

claim: 15 minutes in a sauna will kill the coronavirus.
explaination: Infectious disease epidemiologist debunked this

claim: Eating bananas prevents coronavirus.
explaination: The video splices together clips to make incorrect and misleading information.

claim: Italy has mandated no treatment of all elderly patients for coronavirus.
explaination: The guidelines to ration care to those with higher survivability are only suggestions at this point.

claim: All U.S. citizens are entitled to $700 per week to stay at home to avoid spread of coronavirus.
explaination: U.S. citizens may get some economic relief from Congress at some point, but that could still be a few weeks away.

claim: List comparing diseases with coronavirus.
explaination: The comparison of the outbreaks is extremely misleading as it doesn't take into account the rate of infections, timeframes of the outbreaks and the rapid rise in the number of COVID-19 cases.

claim: COVID-19 is a scripted narrative to justify closed borders or force residents to remain home.
explaination: Debunked as a conspiracy theory.

claim: Italy official Giulio Gallera: China lies to us. The date China provided is false. Italy has become Wuhan and the medical system has a breakdown.
explaination: The Health and Welfare Regional Minister in Lombardy, Giulio Gallera, didn't give such statements in the interview.

claim: Coronil drops can help cure coronavirus.
explaination: Leading homeopaths say that very little is known about the composition of this medicine and it will be careless to recommend this medicine for coronavirus

claim: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St. Patrick’s Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.
explaination: Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4pm on St Patrick's Day - but it has nothing to do with coronavirus

claim: Video shows Chinese police crackdown on coronavirus patients.
explaination: The video actually dates back to August 2019 when anti-government protests were happening in Hong Kong. The visuals pertain to an incident of police crackdown at Prince Edward station in Kowloon where the police personnel and riot police arrived after reports of a tussle between pro-government and anti-government protesters.

claim: A graphic has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook alongside a claim it contains a quote from Philippine Vice President Leni Robredo that bats are the “enemy” in the novel coronavirus pandemic. The graphic is attributed to Inquirer.net, a Philippine media outlet.
explaination: The claim is false; the graphic has been doctored from an earlier Inquirer.net post in which Robredo was quoted about confusion surrounding the government’s response to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: A photo of a room lined with coffins shows Italian nationals killed during the novel coronavirus pandemic in 2020.
explaination: The claim is false; the photo actually shows coffins for a group of dead migrants at an Italian airport in October 2013 after their boat sank off the coast of Italy.

claim: 14 University of Nairobi students have tested positive for COVID-19.
explaination: An article by Times Live claiming that 14 students from the University of Nairobi are infected with coronavirus cites a non-existent news story by KTN News.

claim: Philippines Vice President Leni Robredo says “bats, not the virus, are our enemy.”
explaination: The Vice President did not say what was attributed to her. Robredo’s camp said it is a fake quote, and the Facebook accounts that posted the fake quote the earliest on Facebook failed to give Rappler their source.

claim: The WHO coronavirus test “was a bad test.”
explaination: A review found the World Health Organization’s test did not give false positives when similar viruses were present. The White House provided no evidence that the WHO test fell short.

claim: “All U.S. citizens are entitled to $700 USD per week to stay at home to avoid the spread of COVID-19 novel coronavirus, starting 3/17/20.”
explaination: Americans could receive a check for $1,000 or more as part of an economic stimulus package amid the coronavirus. A Facebook post about weekly $700 checks is a hoax.

claim: “I’ve always known this is a real, this is a pandemic. I’ve felt it was a pandemic long before it was called a pandemic.”
explaination: In January, Trump said there were no worries about a pandemic. In late February, he said the virus was “very much under control.” Trump did activate federal measures to contain the spread in late January.

claim: “People are going door to door in Colorado Springs stating they are COVID-19 testing so they can rob people!”
explaination: Colorado Springs police said they’ve received no reports of robbers pretending to offer coronavirus testing.

claim: “U.S. deaths since 1/22/20: COVID-19, 27; flu, 4,700; abortion, 118,000.”
explaination: The post’s numbers are inaccurate, but abortions do far outnumber deaths from COVID-19 and flu. The COVID-19 number is likely too low, and the flu number is too high. The number of abortions is roughly accurate.

claim: Says it was “unquestionably” not within his “legal authority” to postpone Illinois’ primary election by changing the date or shifting to vote-by-mail.
explaination: It’s difficult to know for sure that Pritzker could not have done anything to delay the March 17 election. But experts told us the governor spoke correctly in describing the limits of his powers under existing law.

claim: Novel coronavirus can be eliminated by drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water mixed with salt or vinegar.
explaination: At present, there is no study or evidence to support the claim.

claim: President Trump’s use of data for deaths from swine flu and seasonal flu.
explaination: Trump is comparing apples and oranges. The figures he cites for the swine flu and seasonal influenza are after-the-fact estimates that try to account for all excess deaths that could be, in some way, attributed to a flu infection. Studies indicate that the official lab counts may be missing as many as 9 in 10 deaths.

claim: Having a beard increases your chances of getting coronavirus.
explaination: The CDC never told anyone to shave their beards, a 2017 graphic circulating the web from the CDC was put out to show the effectiveness of masks with facial hair. The work-place graphic is unrelated to the current coronavirus.

claim: Taking a hot bath, breathing in hot steam or using a hand dryer to blow hot air up the nose are effective ways to prevent COVID-19, according to a lecturer in health sciences faculty at Ghanaian university.
explaination: No evidence for claims, which go counter to WHO recommendations.

claim: An image shows a train transporting the COVID-19 virus.
explaination: The dark wagons on the image are the ones used to transport oil and they have to obey the 4 letters and 6 digits rules. That’s not what happens with the word “COVID-19” that appears in the image. Also, the name of the virus is Sars-Cov-2 and not COVID-19 (that’s the name of the disease). If the train was transporting the virus it would mention “Sars-Cov-2” and not “COVID-19”.

claim: 3,000 Ecuadorians are infected with coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: “While all COVID-19 news has been going on, the U.S. government has been sneakily trying to remove end-to-end encryption” which means “the government will be able to see all of your messages and listen to all of your calls.”
explaination: A bill currently being considered by Congress, called the EARN IT Act, would make it easier for law enforcement to demand information from technology companies about certain users of their services. The bill wouldn't grant unlimited access. Any request would have to be premised on a link to suspected child exploitation.

claim: Did Donald Trump attempt to steal a COVID-19 vaccine from a German company and refuse testing kits from WHO?
explaination: Reports that Trump tried to pay a German company for the rights to a vaccine are not confirmed, and the U.S. government did not refuse tests from the World Health Organization.

claim: Clinics in the Philippines are turning away people with COVID-19 symptoms, because of a advisory from the department of health.
explaination: The claim is false; the Philippine Department of Health denied issuing the advisory.

claim: Red soap and white handkerchiefs are good against the coronavirus.
explaination: But the recommended practices are misleading; health experts told AFP there is no scientific basis for many of the claims, which include using red-coloured soap and white handkerchiefs, as well as obtaining specific light bulbs.

claim: Israel allegedly developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
explaination: The claim is misleading; the image used to illustrate a vial of the new drug is originally a stock picture while the MIGAL Research Institute in Israel, despite having a head start, continues to work on a vaccine for COVID-19.

claim: A video on Facebook and YouTube purports to show billionaire businessman Jack Ma praising China’s response to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus.
explaination: But the video has been doctored; the original video shows Jack Ma at a meeting of former Alibaba employees in 2018, at least one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan; the voiceover in the clip has been taken from another clip which shows a different man speaking.

claim: Indian industrialist tweets that a specific mask can kill viruses.
explaination: The mask is an anti-pollution mask and its effect on COVID-19 is not scientifically explained.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo’s hotels to be turned into quarantine centres in Portugal.
explaination: Footballer's hotel chains denied any such claims.

claim: Chinese police crack down on suspected coronavirus patients.
explaination: Video is originally from the Hong Kong protests.

claim: Nostradamus predicted COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Italian doctors recommend taking off shoes when you get home.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Christine Lagarde says the elderly are living too long.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Ecuadorean President Lenin Moreno and family quarantined in luxury Galapagos home.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: President Donald Trump in the next 48 to 72 hours will impose a nationwide “mandatory quarantine.”
explaination: The White House’s National Security Council addressed the claim in a statement on Twitter, saying: “Text message rumors of a national #quarantine are FAKE. There is no national lockdown.”

claim: Coronavirus pneumonia is similar to a dry cough and hot weather, garlic and hot water are remedies for COVID-19.
explaination: There is no scientific proof that hot and humid weather conditions or drinking warm water and consumption of garlic, onions and other spices can prevent the spread of novel coronavirus infection.

claim: Claims of cures for COVID-19 from multiple countries.
explaination: While some drugs have provided symptomatic improvement, there is no confirmation that any of the medication currently being tested across different parts of the world is a definitive cure for COVID-19. WHO officially confirms there has not been any definitive vaccine or antiviral drug developed to prevent or treat COVID-19 to date, hence all above claims are misleading.

claim: 35 Italians tourists don’t want to leave Ethiopia and go back in Italy because of the coronavirus.
explaination: Testimonies seems to be invented and the characters quoted does not exist. The website is well known for clickbait content and false stories.

claim: All baby formula providers are shipping formula for free during the coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: Enfamil and Gerber issued statements clarifying this is a hoax.

claim: Dallas student celebrating spring break collapses from coronavirus.
explaination: Came from fake news generator website.

claim: Coronavirus is the least deadly virus.
explaination: The chart, published by Business Insider, issued a correction on the chart exaggerating its figures. But the false info still spreads.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo is turning his hotels into hospitals to fight coronavirus.
explaination: Ronaldo's management company denied the claim.

claim: WalMart reducing hours of operation.
explaination: WalMart website confirms

claim: Tanker train marked with “COVID-19” on its side.
explaination: Photo was digitally manipulated

claim: A military Humvee labeled “COVID-19 quarantine team” was on Interstate 696 in Michigan.
explaination: The same image has been shared and described as a vehicle spotted in Ohio and London in the United Kingdom.

claim: President Donald Trump is “announcing tomorrow that the U.S. is going into quarantine for the next 14 days.”
explaination: There was no evidence by March 16 that the federal government was set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said he was not considering it. Trump said the government is thinking about additional measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in some hotspots around the country.

claim: President Donald Trump “will evoke (sic) what is called the Stafford act” and “order a two week mandatory quarantine for the nation.”
explaination: There is no evidence that the federal government is set to announce a nationwide lockdown. President Trump said March 16 that he was not considering it. The Stafford Act authorizes aid to state and local governments and is commonly used during hurricanes. It does not mandate a nationwide lockdown.

claim: “Now, as it stands, our health care system has adequate ventilators, ICU beds, medical professionals.”
explaination: Experts said all evidence points to the U.S. being short on hospital beds, ICUs and ventilators, assuming COVID-19 continues to spread. The U.S. could take any number of actions to increase the number of hospital beds, supplies and medical staff available.

claim: Claim that Dr. Anthony Fauci’s statement that the coronavirus death rate is 10 times that of the seasonal flu is “a claim without any scientific basis.”
explaination: It’s not yet known what the death rate from the current coronavirus, COVID-19, will be. But early data indicate it is more than 10 times higher than the death rate for the flu.

claim: “Sunlight actually can kill the [novel coronavirus].”
explaination: This is a common theory because sunlight contains ultraviolet rays, which can kill bacteria. However, experts say the sun's UV light isn't intense enough to rely on as a disinfectant.

claim: Video shows problems faced by Chinese police while catching coronavirus-infected people.
explaination: The video has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic. It was shot last year in September during Hong Kong's ongoing pro-democracy protest.

claim: Flu vaccine increases coronavirus risk 36%, says military study.
explaination: More research is needed to provide a conclusive answer to the question of whether the flu shot increases the risk of non-influenza viral respiratory infections. It is important to keep in mind that while the flu vaccine cannot prevent COVID-19, it still provides several indirect benefits. For example, it reduces cases of flu and flu complications that require hospitalization, in turn reducing the burden on the healthcare system, which has become strained during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claim: Ecuadorian President Lenin Moreno and family quarantined in luxury Galapagos home.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: No evidence that 5G is being forcibly installed in schools.
explaination: Schools have been closed, but no evidence it's to install 5G. It's to protect against the pandemic.

claim: The government is closing businesses to stop the spread of coronavirus even though “the numbers are nothing compared to H1N1 or Ebola. Everyone needs to realize our government is up to something …”
explaination: Any suggestion that the coronavirus isn't real or that it’s part of a government conspiracy is a ridiculous claim.

claim: A charitable hospital in Pakistan charged patients for novel coronavirus tests.
explaination: But the claim is misleading; the hospital, which was founded by Prime Minister Imran Khan, denied charging a fee, saying in a statement that eligible patients have been receiving free tests; the health minister of Punjab also denied the claim.

claim: Claim that football star Cristiano Ronaldo has converted his hotel chain into coronavirus hospitals.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: The novel coronavirus is not new.
explaination: This is false; coronaviruses affecting cattle or canines differ from the new virus strain affecting humans, for which no vaccine exists.

claim: Ugandan president announces the postponement of elections.
explaination: The claim is false; an electoral commission official issued a flat denial, labelling the claim “nonsensical”.

claim: A video shows how the coronavirus is transmitted between people
explaination: The claim is false; the video was produced by a regional hospital trust within the UK’s public healthcare system, the National Health Service (NHS), in May 2010 about how infections spread in hospitals.

claim: Chinese intelligence officer reveals coronavirus is a bioweapon.
explaination: The story originated from a reddit thread which discusses horror stories inspired by true events.

claim: Indian Daily Reports That Wife Of A Positive Patient Ran Away, did not comply with the authorities and tested positive.
explaination: The Indian daily misreported as the woman had not yet tested positive and she did not flee so as to not be tested.

claim: Audio claiming India would be put under a complete lockdown.
explaination: The government rubbished claims of there being such a lockdown.

claim: A meme posted offers mixed advice — some true, some false — about coronavirus protection.
explaination: The claims in this meme are muddled.

claim: “Bill Gates told us about the coronavirus in 2015.”
explaination: In the 2015 TED talk featured in the video, he never actually uses the word coronavirus, nor does he mention COVID-19. But his comments do sound prescient. He talks about an epidemic and we're now in the midst of a pandemic. People could be infected with COVID-19 and not show symptoms for days, if at all. And it’s mainly spread between people in close contact through respiratory droplets when someone coughs or sneezes.

claim: Graphics with information about COVID-19 containing UNICEF branding and inaccurate information.
explaination: A series of infographics with Unicef branding making claims about COVID-19 are not from the UN agency.

claim: A situation update allegedly from Kenya’s Citizen TV stating the number of COVID-19 cases.
explaination: A post is with an update about COVID-19 in Kenya containing a screenshot of a Facebook post by Citizen TV is fake.

claim: A meme shows an image of fully stocked shelves of toilet paper, purportedly during the 2009 H1N1 outbreak, above barren shelves during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.
explaination: The post is misleading; the image of the stocked shelves is a screenshot from US news footage shot this year, not in 2009.

claim: A video viewed more than 2.4 million times on Facebook urges people to inhale steam to “kill” the novel coronavirus.
explaination: But experts say that doing so will not treat or cure the viral infection, and could in fact be harmful.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple posts on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube which claim it shows Chinese police arresting people infected with the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; the video shows police arresting pro-democracy protesters at a subway station in Hong Kong in August 2019.

claim: Research made by scientists from the University of Queensland in Australia has proven that bananas improve your immune system and help prevent COVID-19.
explaination: The University of Queensland dismissed the claim as false. In an email to Rappler, the university’s communication team said: “The video is fake and we would strongly discourage people from sharing this information. We would suggest you share your concerns with the social media platforms.”

claim: The WHO offered the testing kits that they have available and to give it to us now. We refused them. We did not want to buy them.”
explaination: The WHO never offered to sell test kits to the United States. The CDC opted to develop its own coronavirus test and did not use the WHO’s protocol for the test.

claim: The claim that there is a cure from the new coronavirus. The name of the drug is decametoxine.
explaination: There is no proof that the drug in question can be used in the treatment of coronavirus-infected.

claim: “COVID-19 started because we eat animals.”
explaination: Scientists think COVID-19 originated in bats and then jumped to another animal host, possibly pangolins, before spreading to humans. As of now, there is no evidence that eating meat is the source of the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: “George Soros owns the WuXi PHARMA LAB located in Wuhan, China, where COVID-19 was developed and conveniently broke out.”
explaination: George Soros has invested in WuXi in the past, but he does not own it. Research shows the genetic makeup of COVID-19 precludes it from being man-made.

claim: Coronavirus is just “the damn flu.”
explaination: Coronavirus and the flu do have similarities in spread and symptoms, but there are huge differences in the death rate and ability to treat coronavirus.

claim: “So Oscar Health, the company tapped by Trump to profit from covid tests, is a Kushner company. Imagine that, profits over national safety.”
explaination: Oscar Health does have ties to the Kushner family through Jared Kushner and more directly through Jared’s brother, Joshua Kushner. Oscar Health created a website for finding coronavirus testing locations. The project was launched on the same day that Trump announced a similar partnership with Google.

claim: Says businesses will give you free baby formula during the coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: Several formula producers have released statements saying the rumor is a hoax.

claim: Footballer Ronaldo is turning his hotels into COVID-19 hospitals.
explaination: No evidence Ronaldo's luxury hotels in Portugal are being turned into hospitals.

claim: No coronavirus in Nigeria yet, according to pastor.
explaination: The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control reported the country’s first case of coronavirus on 27 February – more than two weeks before pastor's video was posted on YouTube. A second case was confirmed on 9 March.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo is going to transform his hotels into hospitals.
explaination: It’s not true that the Portuguese football player is doing this. Observador spoke with sources close to the Hotels and the player and found out that it was false.

claim: Did genetic mutations cause the coronavirus to become more dangerous.
explaination: Infectious disease specialist said no proof that mutation specifically caused virus to be more dangerous.

claim: A graphic claims that gargling warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

claim: Cristiano Ronaldo will convert his hotels into coronavirus hospitals.
explaination: A spokesperson for the hotels said the claim was “inaccurate”; Ronaldo has also not mentioned any such plan on his social media platforms.

claim: Curfew issued for Bossier city due to coronavirus.
explaination: The article itself says it's a joke and a prank.

claim: Coronavirus is found in crab legs.
explaination: Image did not actually come out of real broadcast with typos, and came from an app that let people make their own stories.

claim: Military on streets of Philadelphia preparing to invoke martial law and bring citizens to FEMA camps.
explaination: Lt. Col. Keith Hickox, the state public affairs officer said the information was false.

claim: Article overstates threat of coronavirus.
explaination: The claims in the article are backed by science.

claim: Drinking lots of water and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the novel coronavirus. Spread the information as you can save someone.
explaination: According to GMA news report, saline gargles or gargling with water and salt will provide no protection against or cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus acute respiratory disease (2019-nCoV ARD). The report also carried a statement by the Dr. Eric Domingo “I think this is a home remedy that has been followed for many, many generations and I don't think there’s going to be any harm in doing it. Saline gargle has always been advocated to improve mostly symptoms of sore throat...I don't think there is any evidence that it will kill a virus,” Domingo said.

claim: Ireland is going into a full lockdown.
explaination: Despite two messages which were widely shared on WhatsApp, the country did not go into a full military lockdown with the army patrolling the streets. Shops have not been restricted in their opening hours and public transport has not been cancelled.

claim: A post shows a rail freight tanker with “COVID-19” stamped on one side.
explaination: The image has circulated globally but it is false, the tanker operating company said. And Railinc, a corporation that manages an industry-wide database, said there is no such mark as “COVID.”

claim: A graphic has been shared thousands of times on Facebook which claims that gargling warm water with salt or vinegar can eliminate the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

claim: Gargling salt with water “eliminates” the 2019 novel coronavirus.
explaination: Local and international health authorities have said there is not enough study that proves gargling water with salt eliminates the novel coronavirus. To date, there is still no known cure for it.

claim: Former senator Antonio Trillanes IV allegedly posted a tweet saying that President Rodrigo Duterte is to blame for calamities the country has been facing, including the novel coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The tweet came from an account posing as Trillanes. Using his official Twitter account, the former senator explained how the username of the account is different from the one he’s using.

claim: Astrologers had predicted the appearance of a coronavirus in 2020.
explaination: Horoscopes and astro forecasts have no scientific basis.

claim: “Italy has decided not to treat their elderly for this virus.”
explaination: Italy, second only to China in the number of COVID-19 cases, hasn't decided to stop treating elderly COVID-19 patients. But the elderly are a lower priority because they are less likely to survive, and hospitals are overwhelmed with coronavirus cases.

claim: Says that “over a 45-minute period that we had the press conference” on the coronavirus on March 13, 2020, the stock market set “an all-time record.”
explaination: The Dow had a record-high point increase on the day Trump declared a national emergency in response to coronavirus, with the surge accelerating during his late-afternoon news conference. But that followed a record point decrease the previous day. And it was followed by a sharp drop by the opening of the next trading day, which saw continued declines before closing.

claim: A Cuban vaccine cured 1.500 people infected with the new coronavirus.
explaination: There is still no vaccine available in the market, according to Health Authorities. Experts estimate that it will take about 18 months to develop and test a vaccine that can be used with safety in human beings.

claim: Warm water with salt prevents the new coronavirus infection, killing it in the throat.
explaination: There is no scientific evidence to support this theory. Several experts had already explained that there’s no connection between the act of drinking water and the virus.

claim: The Simpsons had already predicted the coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: It’s not true, because the images that are shown to illustrate this were manipulated and are not in accordance with the original images of the series.

claim: Gargling warm salt water or vinegar prevents coronavirus infection.
explaination: The claim is false; international health authorities and experts do not list gargling as an effective remedy or prevention method for COVID-19.

claim: If you drink water with lemon, it prevents the new coronavirus.
explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. Health authorities have never made any recommendations regarding water and lemon. It’s not proved.

claim: LGBTQ people in the US are demanding to be treated first for coronavirus.
explaination: Pulpit and Pen quotes a Reuters article about an open letter signed by more than 100 LGBTQ rights groups, calling on organisations handling the global coronavirus pandemic to remember “that LGBTQ+ communities are among those who are particularly vulnerable to the negative health effects of this virus”. But it doesn't ask for anyone to be given priority treatment.

claim: Claim from an “uncle” who “graduated with a master’s degree” and worked at Shenzhen Hospital offers advice on COVID-19 symptoms and treatment.
explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to contain a mixture of true and false claims. A runny nose, sputum, dry cough and pneumonia can be symptoms of COVID-19 however not everyone infected with the disease will have them. Disease expert Prof Collignon says temperatures around 26 to 27 degrees C won't kill the virus however UV light from the sun can be effective in drying out the virus. Understanding of how long COVID-19 survives on surfaces is limited, with the WHO referring to previous studies of other viruses to estimate a range of a few hours to a few days. Drinking warm water, avoiding iced drinks and gargling warm salt water are not treatments or preventions, according to Prof Cunningham, however staying hydrated is important and gargling may relieve sore throats. The timeline for progression of COVID-19 symptoms is partly accurate but not everyone will experience all of these symptoms or in that order. Prof Cunningham also said it was not accurate to say infection will happen first in the throat, as the delicate tissues behind the nose are more likely starting points.

claim: False COVID-19 hotline number shared in Canada.
explaination: 811 is not an official public health hotline in Ontario, and the provincial ministry of health is not organizing home visits, a spokeswoman told AFP.

claim: Israel has no cases of the coronavirus because it developed a cure.
explaination: Official World Health Organization (WHO) data and Israeli media reports state at least 298 people have been confirmed to have contracted the disease as of March 16; Israel has implemented travel restrictions and closed businesses in response to the spread of COVID-19. Various countries have been working develop a vaccine for COVID-19 and WHO guidance currently states there is no "cure" for the virus to date.

claim: Books predicted the coronavirus before it happened.
explaination: One book does have a close enough accurate representation, the second is a work of fiction.

claim: Israel and USA have come up with a vaccine.
explaination: Israel has found a vaccine with properties similar to COVID-19, San Diego had developed an algorithm.

claim: A misleading chart being spread on Facebook, erroneously dubbing the new coronavirus the “least deadly virus.”
explaination: The chart cites old data about coronavirus cases and deaths, and it contains an error that makes COVID-19 look less fatal than the 2009 H1N1 “swine flu” outbreak.

claim: Indian Ministry of Health and Family Welfare issued an office memorandum declaring compulsory holiday in four Indian states.
explaination: Ministry of Health India has denied any such notification.

claim: People are panicked about a COVID-19 case at the Dakar Airport.
explaination: this footage has nothing to do with the coronavirus pandemic and was taken out of context from a Senegalese TV footage showing an exercise.

claim: The coronavirus scare began after impeachment.
explaination: the outbreak began in China in late 2019, and it led to the World Health Organization to declare a global health emergency on January 30, 2020, before the final impeachment vote.

claim: Supermarkets are recalling coronavirus-infected toilet paper.
explaination: The CDC said that coronavirus is spread through respiratory droplets. No reports yet of toilet paper recalls.

claim: NYC did implement a citywide quarantine.
explaination: NY Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted it was a false alarm.

claim: Israel has manufactured the coronavirus vaccine
explaination: According to Israel, work at The Biological Institute is going on and it may take time. 50 of the most senior researchers and scientists are working hard to prepare a vaccine. The Image which is being circulated along with the claim is a reference image, available on shutterstock.

claim: Central government has announced blanket holiday for schools/colleges in 4 states in India.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: The health service in Ireland is asking people to stockpile food.
explaination: The claim was untrue. The health service is not urging people to stockpile food - in fact, the opposite is true - and the supply chains in Ireland remain robust

claim: Ireland is going into a ‘Status Red’ lockdown with the military patrolling the streets.
explaination: The claim was untrue. Ireland has not gone into lockdown

claim: Staff of Gold Coast Hospital in Australia has gifted a volleyball to Tom Hanks in quarantine.
explaination: The image has been morphed to claim that Tom Hanks was gifted a volleyball.

claim: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
explaination: This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.

claim: A post shared more than 165,000 times on Facebook includes a video of a woman turning a baby wipe into a face mask to “protect against coronavirus.”
explaination: The company that sells the wipes says they should not be used in this way, and health experts also recommend caution.

claim: Eleven coronavirus patients visited malls and hotels in Metro Manila that are part of a “confidential list.”
explaination: The DOH has dismissed the message as fake. The malls and hotels in question have also not posted any advisories regarding possible infection.

claim: A vaccine for the 2019 novel coronavirus has been found and there will be no more deaths due to the coronavirus.
explaination: As of Friday morning, March 20, there is no vaccine or cure for the disease caused by the 2019 novel coronavirus and there have been 217,510 cases and 9,020 deaths, across 157 countries.

claim: “It’s actually the safest time to fly.”
explaination: Older Americans and those with chronic conditions are advised to reconsider all travel plans to avoid COVID-19. The State Department is advising all citizens to reconsider travel abroad.

claim: Drinking “water a lot and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates” the coronavirus.
explaination: Neither drinking a lot of water, nor gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar, has been identified as working against the coronavirus.

claim: In South Florida “all children and adults must remain in their homes” due to coronavirus.
explaination: We looked at announcements from several major local governments in south Florida and found no complete lockdown announcements. Gov. Ron DeSantis closed bars and nightclubs statewide.

claim: “President Trump, COVID-19 coronavirus: U.S. cases 1,329; U.S. deaths, 38; panic level: mass hysteria. President Obama, H1N1 virus: U.S. cases, 60.8 million; U.S. deaths, 12,469; panic level: totally chill. Do you all see how the media can manipulate your life.”
explaination: Numbers that suggest H1N1 was worse than COVID-19 are misleading. It’s too early to calculate how deadly the coronavirus will be, but there are signs it’s much worse.

claim: Says The New York Times exposed the “real reason behind coronavirus hype: Crash the market to harm Trump’s re-election chances.”
explaination: There's no evidence the coronavirus was manufactured. The New York Times story referenced was an analysis of how current events may influence the election.

claim: Picture shows the Mecca totally empty.
explaination: The picture is from a miniature designed by an artist.

claim: Saddam Hussein explains what coronavirus is about.
explaination: Sound has been edited. It's a video from 2003 where Saddam Hussein is talking about the US/Iraq war.

claim: A post says that if you hold your breath you can tell if you are infected with Covid-19 or not.
explaination: A pulmonologist and member of the National Public Health Commission assured that this exercise doesn’t have any clinical applicability and it’s not safe. You can do the exercise, pass it and be infected with Covid-19.

claim: Claim that disease outbreaks and pandemics correspond with election years.
explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found no correlation between election years and virus outbreaks. The outbreaks of SARS, Bird Flu and COVID-19 do not line up with the dates claimed in the post. In the case of Zika virus, the disease has had multiple outbreaks since 2014 in parts of Oceania and in Brazil. Bird Flu, MERS and Ebola have not been reported in Australia and have not been a significant feature of local political discussion or debate. Considering overseas elections, such as US presidential elections, there is also no consistent pattern of outbreaks occurring in election years.

claim: Photo purportedly showing Tom Hanks holding a volleyball, claiming the hospital staff in Australia gave it to him as a tribute and to cheer him up while in quarantine.
explaination: The image has been doctored using a 2015 photograph of Hanks and a stock photo of a hospital ward; the doctored photo emerged on a satirical website.

claim: Photos show empty shelves at supermarkets.
explaination: The photos have circulated online since 2015.

claim: A video purports to show body bags for virus victims in Italy.
explaination: It has previously circulated in media reports about people who died after contracting COVID-19 in Iran; a man recording the video can be heard stating that he is inside a mortuary in the Iranian city of Qom.

claim: KFC San Marino Shopping (Guayaquil, Ecuador) employee with COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Jair Bolsonaro tested positive for COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Policemen in China chase COVID-19 in a subway station.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
explaination: The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching this lady because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.

claim: The U.S. presidential election is canceled due to coronavirus.
explaination: The federal government has made no such announcement about canceling the U.S. presidential election.

claim: A former and controversial CIA officer said coronavirus was made in a lab.
explaination: The quote was pulled out of context and was mere speculation, not fact.

claim: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
explaination: Medical practitioners and even WHO has rubbished this claim and has said that there is no evidence to prove that turmeric and lemon can be used to cure coronavirus.

claim: Drinking water every 15 minutes will protect you from getting coronavirus.
explaination: There is no medical evidence to support the idea that drinking water every 15 minutes will help protect you from coronavirus.

claim: You can check for coronavirus by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
explaination: There is no evidence to support the claim that holding your breath for several seconds is an effective way to test for coronavirus

claim: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he’s quarantined.
explaination: The image of Tom Hanks apparently holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine comes from a satirical Australian website.

claim: A fake quote of Vice President Leni Robredo suggesting to “inhale cough back” to prevent the spread of the 2019 novel coronavirus.
explaination: The Vice President did not say what was attributed to her in the graphic. News5 said the graphic was edited using their template.

claim: If you donate blood, “they HAVE to test you” for coronavirus.
explaination: Blood donors don’t get a coronavirus test if they donate blood.

claim: “During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden made reckless comments unsupported by science & the experts. The Obama Admin had to clean up his mess & apologize for his ineptitude.”
explaination: During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.

claim: Donald Trump claims Joe Biden “was in charge of the H1N1 Swine Flu epidemic which killed thousands of people. The response was one of the worst on record. Our response is one of the best, with fast action of border closings and a 78% approval rating, the highest on record. His was lowest!”
explaination: Joe Biden was not in charge of the Obama administration’s H1N1 response. Trump overstated public confidence in his administration’s response to the coronavirus and downplayed confidence in the Obama administration’s response to H1N1.

claim: Says Nancy Pelosi was “caught trying to include abortion funding in bill to combat coronavirus.”
explaination: The U.S. House passed a measure that provides federal funds to people affected by the coronavirus. The bill covers reimbursement laboratory costs for COVID-19 testing. Some raised concerns that language was needed to specifically ensure abortion services weren't eligible to receive funds. The language was amended by Democrats to limit reimbursements to COVID-19 expenses.

claim: In 2007, “The Simpsons” predicted Tom Hanks would contract coronavirus in 2007.
explaination: In the closing credits of “The Simpson Movie,” Hanks says: "This is Tom Hanks, saying, if you see me in person, leave me be." The movie is about an environmental crisis. There’s no reference to any kind of outbreak.

claim: “The CDC can detain anyone with a fever indefinitely. Vaccination (is) a way people could get out of detention.”
explaination: In the United States, people can't be quarantined for just having a fever; they have to be shown to have been exposed to one of a specific set of diseases. Most quarantines are done voluntarily, not by force of the government. And vaccination is not a ticket out of quarantine. Most quarantine decisions are up to states and localities, rather than the CDC.

claim: COVID-19 came to the United States in 2019.
explaination: The first confirmed COVID-19 case in the United States was reported on Jan. 20, 2020. The patient was a man who had recently returned to Washington state from Wuhan, China.

claim: Saint Luke’s Hospital of the USA says consuming alcohol can reduce the risk of COVID-19.
