explaination: Saint Luke's Hospital hasn't released any such advisory.

claim: Chart compares COVID-19 with other longstanding diseases.
explaination: The graphic is misleading and risks underplaying the danger of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, which is a new disease with a fast-rising mortality rate.

claim: Actor Daniel Radcliffe tested positive for covid-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Quito is the second city with the highest probability of infection.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For Coronavirus.
explaination: Anti- Malaria drug Chloroquine is not an authorized medicine to cure coronavirus. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can be used to cure COVID-19.

claim: Racist scene against Chinese people in the metro in Belgium.
explaination: Vidéo is an excerpt of the Youtube channel "Would you react" with actors.

claim: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.
explaination: Anti-fascist demonstration on February 22 in Roma.

claim: Coronavirus found in toilet paper.
explaination: This was created by a prank generator, and the CDC did not include this as a way in which coronavirus spreads.

claim: Gargling salt water and vinegar will kill the virus.
explaination: Pulmonologist debunked the memes, and CDC offers real advice about how to say safe.

claim: Uganda did not deport 19 passengers from high-risk COVID-19 countries.
explaination: Ugandan authorities did not deport 19 passengers on a KLM flight from Amsterdam to Entebbe. The passengers did not show 'severe' flu-like symptoms.

claim: American CDC admitted that coronavirus originated in the U.S. Many COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as coronavirus.
explaination: It is another piece of false information based on the unfounded claim that the coronavirus came from the United States.

claim: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26-27 degrees Celsius as per UNICEF.
explaination: The viral message on novel coronavirus is NOT issued by UNICEF.

claim: Indian yoga guru Baba Ramdev has been infected with coronavirus.
explaination: An old picture of Ramdev from the year 2011 is being shared with a false caption. The picture was taken in Dehradun after the yoga guru broke his nine-day fast. He had been on a hunger strike demanding tougher a law against corruption and seeking the return of black money stashed abroad.

claim: “NYC man drops dead in middle of street — suspected coronavirus!”
explaination: New York City Police say a man was taken to the hospital after falling and hitting his head. He was in stable condition and it was unrelated to coronavirus, according to police.

claim: The health insurance industry has “agreed to waive all co-payments for coronavirus treatments.”
explaination: Health insurance companies said they will waive costs for coronavirus tests, not treatment. A shortage in diagnostic supplies means that testing is limited.

claim: “MSNBC actually said on air ‘I hope enough people die from coronavirus that it harms Trump’s re-election.’”
explaination: MSNBC panelists compared former President George W. Bush’s response to Hurricane Katrina to President Donald Trump’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, and speculated it could hurt his popularity.

claim: Panic scene in Germany with people rushing into a supermarket.
explaination: The video is taken during the sales.

claim: Actor Daniel Radcliffe tested positive for COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Purported government advisory lists shopping malls and hotels in the Philippines that the department of health advises against visiting during the novel coronavirus epidemic.
explaination: The claim is misleading; the Philippine Department of Health said the purported advisory is "fake”.

claim: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.
explaination: Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician.The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who was having a sore back at the time.

claim: Senegalese president and government appears with masks during a press conference.
explaination: The picture is digitally edited to add the masks.

claim: 10,000 deaths In virus outbreak in Michigan, Washington, Idaho, North Dakota, Missouri, Mississippi.
explaination: The CDC counted 25 deaths and 647 confirmed coronavirus cases in the United States as of March 10, 2020.

claim: Tweet says Daniel Radcliffe has the coronavirus.
explaination: A fake BBC Twitter account spread the claim before the tweet was removed and the account suspended from the platform.

claim: Post says Harvard scientists say the coronavirus is “spreading so fast that it will infect 70% of humanity this year.”
explaination: An epidemiologist at Harvard University projects 40%-70% of adults could catch coronavirus in the coming year.

claim: You can monitor yourself for COVID-19 with a breath test.
explaination: Holding your breath for 10 seconds isn’t a way to test that you don't have COVID-19.

claim: UNICEF ​​advises not to eat ice cream because it reinforces infection with the new coronavirus.
explaination: Unicef has already denied this information in public, releasing an official statement explaining that this statement is a lie.

claim: First patient healed in Algeria.
explaination: The man is from Morocco and appears in a TV ad for an hospital in Morocco.

claim: Does Mexico have confirmed cases of COVID-19?
explaination: Johns Hopkins coronavirus Resource Center has records showing Mexico has COVID-19 cases.

claim: Anti-malaria drug Chloroquine is a definitive cure for COVID-19.
explaination: A study found the molecule showed 'apparent efficacy' in treating the disease, trials are still ongoing.

claim: Costco recalls toilet paper because it’s infected with the coronavirus.
explaination: The notice is not authentic, according to a statement from the wholesaler, and the brand of bath tissue in question is not listed on official recall websites.

claim: Donating blood in the U.S. can get you a novel coronavirus test.
explaination: The two organizations who collect the vast majority of blood in US said they were not testing for COVID-19

claim: Video claims to show a hotel collapsing in Chinese city of Quanzhou after it was used as a coronavirus quarantine facility.
explaination: The video has circulated online since at least April 2017 about a hotel demolition in China’s Jiangsu province.

claim: Video shows reciting Namaaz and Quran is the only treatment for COVID-19.
explaination: BOOM looked at the video and found several indications about it being a 'Viral Test', Aaj Tak's show where it debunks false claims.

claim: UNICEF advises a certain set of steps to follow for coronavirus.
explaination: UNICEF has not released this advisory and most of the claims are not scientifically backed.

claim: Hand sanitizer will “do nothing for the coronavirus.”
explaination: CDC says hand sanitizers with 60% alcohol can be used to help prevent contracting and spreading the virus.

claim: Freshly boiled garlic water is a cure for coronavirus.
explaination: There is still no cure.

claim: Department of Homeland Security official says illegal border crossings may spread coronavirus.
explaination: No officials were quoted to confirm this. Headline is mainly the false part.

claim: Israeli scientists at the MIGAL Research Institute have developed a vaccine for COVID-19.
explaination: Researchers at the MIGAL Institute in Israel have announced a breakthrough in research into the novel coronavirus, but they have not developed a vaccine as claimed.

claim: Pier Luigi Bersani: None of the confirmed cases are related to China. Coronavirus might have occured in Italy before China.
explaination: In the interview, Bersani didn't say that the virus is originated from Italy. In contrast, he emphasized that the virus is from China. His point is to bring up the assumption that the virus came to Italy prior to the time WHO declared the emergency.

claim: Post says “President Trump has come into contact with a potential coronavirus sufferer!”
explaination: There is no evidence President Donald Trump came into direct contact with a coronavirus sufferer.

claim: “(Former U.S. President Barack Obama) set up anti-pandemic programs in 47 vulnerable countries as a way to protect against something like the coronavirus. Do you know that Trump closed 37 of them?”
explaination: News reports in early 2018 said the CDC was preparing to scale back its anti-pandemic programs in some countries because an early source of funding was running out and the agency didn't expect to receive new money from the Trump administration.The spending bills that lawmakers ultimately passed provided more money for those CDC programs than Trump’s budget requests asked for.

claim: “An entire family” in Santolan, Pasig, is “confirmed to be infected” with the novel coronavirus, according to what looked like a breaking news graphic from GMA News.
explaination: Pasig City Mayor Vico Sotto called the graphic a “fake ‘GMA’ post.” Moreover, the social media team of GMA News said they did not release the “JUST IN” graphic that circulated online.

claim: Chinese eating exotic animals is the cause of the 2019 novel coronavirus, as shown in photos shared on Facebook.
explaination: Some of the photos in the viral Facebook post were not taken in China. Moreover, as of Friday, March 13, there are still not enough studies available that confirm the source of the 2019 novel coronavirus.

claim: Says 80% of novel coronavirus cases are “mild.”
explaination: The website Information is Beautiful published a chart showing that 80.9% of novel coronavirus cases are "mild." But reports from the World Health Organization and the U.S. CDC found that mild cases account for 75-to-80% of all cases.

claim: “Coronavirus — 22. Clintons — 39.”
explaination: Conspiracies linking the Clintons to various deaths are longstanding and unsubstantiated. We've debunked a number of them. The novel coronavirus has killed thousands globally.

claim: This photo shows the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The photo is a magnified photo of a weevil.

claim: The mayor of Buga, Valle del Cauca, said: “I invite the people of Buga to keep calm and to live each day as if it was the last.”
explaination: He never said this.

claim: Hot air from hair dryers can kill the coronavirus.
explaination: Blowing hot air from hair dryer is not a cure nor a preventive measure against coronavirus. There is no cure for coronavirus as of now.

claim: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities dismissed the claim, calling it “absolutely false”; health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.

claim: Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils and the sinus kills the novel coronavirus.
explaination: Fact Crescendo found the above-mentioned post to be False. Hot air application through a hairdryer on the face to heat up nostrils will not kill the coronavirus.

claim: Consuming colloidal silver can prevent or treat novel coronavirus.
explaination: US regulators say consuming silver is not safe for use against any disease.

claim: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explaination: The claim is misleading; the photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

claim: Smoking prevents you from getting infected with the coronavirus.
explaination: The WHO says smoking does not protect a person from COVID-19 infection and warns it can actually cause health conditions that increase the risk of severe coronavirus illness.

claim: Telangana Ministry in India distributed homeopathic tablets claiming to prevent COVID-19.
explaination: BOOM could not find any scientific evidence supporting theory that arsenicum album prevents coronavirus- Follow up to AYUSH story.

claim: As of 3/7/20, Tanzania and Zambia had confirmed fist cases of the new coronavirus.
explaination: At the time, the MP said there were no reported cases in Tanzania. WHO also didn't confirm cases at the time in either country.

claim: A Facebook post shared 25,000 times features an image of a letter purportedly from a U.S. hospital recommending people drink alcohol to help reduce the risks of novel coronavirus infection.
explaination: Saint Luke’s Hospital in Kansas City did not issue the letter, according to its staff.

claim: “More people have died from knowing Hillary (Clinton)” than from coronavirus.
explaination: It’s obviously nonsense to compare Clinton in any way with a global virus outbreak that has killed thousands.

claim: A video has been viewed thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claims to show the Koran being distributed to people in China after it lifted a “ban” on the Islamic holy text following the outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explaination: The claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least 2013 in reports about people receiving copies of the Bible in China.

claim: Graphics or social media cards supposedly from UNICEF contain tips and information on how to prevent and combat the coronavirus outbreak and COVID-19.
explaination: The graphics and the tips are not from Unicef.

claim: Research by the Saint Luke’s Hospital of Kansas City found that consuming alcoholic beverages may reduce the risk of infection by coronavirus. Vodka was the most recommended drink.
explaination: The hospital dismissed the claim as false. Further, the World Health Organization (WHO) does not recommend alcohol consumption to prevent the coronavirus.

claim: U.S. hospitals are preparing for 96 million coronavirus infections and nearly half a million deaths, leaked documents reveal.
explaination: An infectious disease expert presenting to the American Hospital Association estimated there could be as many as 96 million cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. in a year. But there is no indication that hospitals are preparing, covertly, for an outbreak of that magnitude, as this headline suggests.

claim: Vietnam was the first country to contain and develop a quick test for SARS and COVID-19.
explaination: The claims that Vietnam was the first country to contain SARS and developed a quick test kit are mostly legit. We're not sure where the claim that WHO says it takes four years to develop a test kit comes from. But that appears to not be accurate.

claim: An image has been shared alongside a claim that shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explaination: The photos in this image have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

claim: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to be partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the Facebook post are unrelated to COVID-19. It is true that World Health Organization’s advice is there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive”.

claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Muslims to understand why they are not contracting COVID-19.
explaination: BOOM found that the viral video is a combination of three clips of Xi Jinping visiting the northwest region of China in 2016.

claim: The mayor Of Buffalo told people to evacuate due to the coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: The mayor denied this claim when he responded to a Facebook post spreading the misinformation.

claim: CDC sponsored Facebook post asking for help with “escaped” coronavirus patient.
explaination: The post was created by a fake CDC account.

claim: Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg after South Africa announced its first case of novel coronavirus.
explaination: A statement claiming that Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg due to coronavirus is fake.

claim: Girl infected with coronavirus found dead in her apartment in Delhi.
explaination: Contrary to the claim, the incident in the post does not pertain to a coronavirus case in Delhi but is related to the death of a 22-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu’s Chettipedu.

claim: A television news report about a US biotech company runs alongside a claim that the company successfully created a vaccine for the COVID-19 within “three hours.”
explaination: The US biotech company said the vaccine still requires human testing and will not be made available until at least the end of 2020.

claim: Bloggers say Nancy Pelosi delayed coronavirus funding so “Dems could campaign on it.”
explaination: President Donald Trump signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to address the coronavirus on March 6. There is no evidence House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed the bill solely to run political ads.

claim: If the coronavirus gets in your mouth, “drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through your esophagus and into the stomach. Once there, your stomach acid will kill all of the virus.”
explaination: There is no evidence that drinking water helps to prevent coronavirus infection. Health officials and media outlets have debunked the claim.

claim: “Anybody that wants a test (for the coronavirus) can get a test.”
explaination: The CDC says health care providers are the ones who decide whether someone gets tested for coronavirus.

claim: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
explaination: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.

claim: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
explaination: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.

claim: A Shaheen Bagh protest in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
explaination: BOOM contacted hospitals in Delhi and confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protest had tested positive for COVID-19.

claim: Donating plasma or blood is free testing for the coronavirus.
explaination: Currently the test for coronavirus is free.

claim: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
explaination: Reports that two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed over COVID-19 panic are false.

claim: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2 and a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
explaination: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak, as implied in the claim. In addition, the transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number”, is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between around 2 to more than 6.

claim: The coronavirus outbreak is caused by 5G technology.
explaination: There is no causal link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease has been definitively identified in scientific studies as a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiation.

claim: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.
explaination: The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.

claim: Article says that the Vatican confirmed that the Pope and two assistants have coronavirus.
explaination: There’s no official statement from the Vatican saying that Pope Francis is infected with Covid-19. Pope has felt ill, but not with the coronavirus.

claim: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
explaination: Unicef has not released the advisory and many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice.

claim: This video shows panic buying in the United States, during the coronavirus outbreak
explaination: But the video has been shared in a misleading context; it has circulated online since November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: 10 coronavirus cases confirmed in Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: The common cold is the only type of coronavirus.
explaination: Coronaviruses can cause different illnesses in animals and humans, including the common cold. However, they can also lead to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

claim: Officials say coronavirus killed 200 in Iran.
explaination: The number of deaths in official reports on March 3, 2020, were much lower than stated in this article.

claim: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C can stop the spread of coronavirus.
explaination: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus. there is no evidence that the spread of coronavirus can be stopped by consuming large doses of Vitamin C.

claim: “Man visited Albany, N.Y., days before dying from coronavirus.”
explaination: The image appears manipulated so that it looks like it is from ABC News. There is no evidence one of those individuals who died from COVID-19 had recently been to Albany, N.Y.

claim: “The State of Florida has announced measures that all workplaces with 10 employees or more are to have paid mandatory leave to avoid the spread of COVID-19 coronavirus starting on March 6, 2020. All schools are to close for 2 weeks also from March 6.”
explaination: As of March 5, Florida is not shutting down schools and businesses for two weeks.

claim: The media “pulled down an entire shelf of goods so that they can present the news of people buying stuff in a hysteria over the coronavirus.”
explaination: A popular image claims to show a news reporter staging a shot of empty grocery store shelves. But the photo is a hoax from Romania.

claim: The Obama administration “didn’t do anything about” swine flu.
explaination: The Obama administration responded with two emergency declarations, triggering billions in spending and other public health responses.

claim: Trump’s effort to blame Obama for sluggish coronavirus testing.
explaination: Trump is looking for scapegoats to excuse his administration’s sluggish efforts to expand testing. But he cannot blame Obama. There was no “Obama rule,” just draft guidance that never took effect and was withdrawn before Trump took office.

claim: Colombia closes its borders to Ecuadorians.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: 10 coronavirus cases are confirmed in Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Ads are selling masks protecting against COVID-19.
explaination: US authorities don't recommend people to wear masks and the doctor does not speak about CoV.

claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from CoV.
explaination: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

claim: A man is hospitalized after eating a bat.
explaination: This photo has circulated in an online fundraising page for a man with a lung condition unrelated to the novel coronavirus

claim: Russia said COVID-19 is man-made.
explaination: the Russian Ministry of Health said it did not make such a statement; the document cited in the misleading posts states COVID-19 is a “recombinant virus” which can form naturally.

claim: The coronavirus has been discovered in poultry.
explaination: Sri Lankan authorities said the coronavirus has not been discovered in poultry; the photos were taken from various unrelated reports online and show chickens sickened with other diseases.

claim: A Nigerian taxi driver threatens to spread COVID-19.
explaination: The story originated from a parody account and has been denied by the man pictured in the claim and government officials.

claim: The photos show Indians bathing in cow dung to prevent infection.
explaination: The photos show participants at an annual cow dung festival held in the southern region of India in October 2019, several weeks before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

claim: Video shows Wuhan residents lining up for death certificates.
explaination: The video has previously circulated in reports about Wuhan residents gathering to collect free vegetables.

claim: Chinese official detainted a CoV case.
explaination: It was an exercise.

claim: A health expert surmises that the new coronavirus might not spread in Nigeria because of the hot temperature.
explaination: Warmer air holds more moisture; thus preventing airborne viruses from travelling as far as they would in dry air. Still, the jury’s out on whether or not SARS-Cov2 will be resistant or vulnerable to hot temperature.

claim: Ecuadorean doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, in Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Azuay Governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of covid-19 in indigenous medicine.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: An image shows Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer criticizing President Trump’s restrictions on foreign nationals traveling to the U.S. from China.
explaination: It was a fake tweet.

claim: The government — or specific states such as Michigan or Florida — has mandated that employers and schools close for two weeks.
explaination: No such announcement has been made. It was apparently a prank.

claim: Pope Francis and his two aides have been infected with the new coronavirus
explaination: Pope tested negative.

claim: A bovine vaccine can be used to inoculate people against coronavirus.
explaination: There is still currently no approved and public vaccine.

claim: Patents mean deadly diseases and viruses were created or invented in a lab.
explaination: Instead, the patents are for possible treatments or vaccines, some of which were tested but did not work.

claim: An audio clip claims Kenya has recorded 63 cases of COVID-19.
explaination: An audio clip claiming that Kenya has recorded 63 cases of novel coronavirus has been edited and taken out of context. The clip was part of a training exercise by the Ministry of Health to prepare for a likely outbreak ahead of the opening of a quarantine center in Nairobi.

claim: Bloggers say the Vatican reports that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus before a second test came back positive.
explaination: An Italian newspaper reported that Pope Francis tested negative for the coronavirus. The Vatican hasn't confirmed or denied the report.

claim: Video shows President Donald Trump saying COVID-19 is the Democrats’ “new hoax.”
explaination: The video makes it look like Trump called coronavirus “their new hoax.” In fact, there was nearly a full minute between when the president said “coronavirus” and “hoax” during a Feb. 28 rally in North Charleston, S.C.

claim: Ecuadorian doctor develops a vaccine for COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Two cases of coronavirus have been reported in Loja, Ecuador.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Azuay governor in Ecuador seeks the cure of COVID-19 in indigenous medicine.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: This photo shows a brothel in Europe where people have been quarantined.
explaination: Claim originated on a satirical website based in Spain, the photo is of a nightclub in Marbella.

claim: These are seven “evil” things COVID-19 is “afraid” of.
explaination: The claim is misleading; health experts say such practices are only effective when applied properly and can even be harmful if used incorrectly.

claim: A runny nose and sputum secretion are not symptoms of novel coronavirus.
explaination: WHO listed those as possible symptoms.

claim: Israeli scientists have developed a COVID-19 vaccine.
explaination: Israel's migal institute said it was still working to develop a vaccine, the photo is from a stock photo website.

claim: Twitter users said Adutwumwaa Bitters cure coronavirus.
explaination: Adutwumwaa Bitters does not cure coronavirus. Producers of the medicine, Adutwumwaa Herbal Industries Limited, have emphatically stated that their product cannot and does not cure the deadly virus. The World Health Organization (WHO) says there’s no cure, vaccine or specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat coronavirus at the moment.

claim: Constant sex kills coronavirus.
explaination: Sex cannot kill or cure coronavirus, the science does not add up. Rather such close contact with an infected person will expose the partner to the disease.

claim: Viral photo in Nigeria suggests former President Obasanjo said there is no coronavirus in Nigeria and that the minister of health lied.
explaination: President Obasanjo's spokesperson, Kehinde Akinyemi refuted allegations attributed to Baba; a moniker often used to describe the former head of state. Additionally, Dubawa initiated a google reverse image search, which revealed that the "Fox News writer" (the source) used the image out of context.

claim: Ecuadorean youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene supposedly infected with COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: There are cases of coronavirus in the Amazon forest.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn’t “new” and is evidence of “how much the media controls people.”
explaination: The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.

claim: U.S. Vice President Pence urged people with coronavirus to go to the police.
explaination: This is a fake Tweet by Pence. He never said this.

claim: Man critical with novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, India.
explaination: There is no confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in Barhalganj, a town in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh. And the man did not get infected with coronavirus in Barhalganj by consuming chicken. The viral post is fake.

claim: Alcohol kills the coronavirus.
explaination: Post claiming alcohol kills coronavirus is fake.

claim: Post says “sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus.”
explaination: Although it is not effective against all viruses, hand sanitizers with high alcohol content have proven effective against human coronaviruses.

claim: Post says two patients at Valley Regional Medical Center in Brownsville, Texas, “are being looked at” for possible coronavirus infections.
explaination: Health officials say there are no coronavirus patients in the Rio Grande Valley as of March 3, 2020.

claim: The United States is “actually screening fewer people (for the coronavirus than other countries) because we don’t have appropriate testing.”
explaination: The CDC has stopped publicly reporting the number of tests it’s administered. As of March 4, the United States has lagged behind other nations in terms of coronavirus testing.

claim: Multiple videos claim garlic and onions can prevent and cure infection from the novel coronavirus.
explaination: This is false; the World Health Organization says garlic cannot prevent or treat COVID-19.

claim: Ecuadorian youtuber Raùl Alvarez Guene was supposedly infected with COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Local hospital in Ecuador says first COVID-19 patient didn’t have coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: This is a video of panicked shoppers storming a supermarket amid the coronavirus pandemic.
explaination: The claim is false; the video was in fact filmed in Germany in 2011, nearly a decade before the coronavirus pandemic broke out.

claim: Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
explaination: No official Vatican communication confirms this.

claim: “Florida hospital reports a coronavirus ‘infestation’ with multiple confirmed patients.”
explaination: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention presumptively confirmed two cases of the 2019 coronavirus in Florida.

claim: Photo shows a man wearing a “government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”
explaination: The image was posted by a self-described parody account.

claim: “Shands Hospital of Gainesville, Florida, has confirmed its first case of coronavirus.”
explaination: As of March 2, 2020, the CDC has confirmed two cases of COVID-19 in Florida. Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida, has not confirmed a coronavirus case.

claim: Post says no one has died from the coronavirus in the United States.
explaination: As of March 3, nine people have died from the coronavirus in the United States. The first death was on March 1.

claim: The coronavirus is “simply the common cold.”
explaination: The 2019 coronavirus is part of a family of viruses that produce illnesses ranging from the common cold to more critical diseases such as SARS or MERS, but is a new virus that had not been previously identified.

claim: Vatican says Pope Francis has been infected with the novel coronavirus.
explaination: The Vatican said the pope recently fell ill with a common cold..

claim: 14 points of expert advice about coronavirus, including symptoms, prevention and how it spreads.
explaination: Some points are outright false, some misleading -- there isn't enough research on the virus to make these claims.

claim: Mongolia donates 30,000 sheep to China during the coronavirus epidemic.
explaination: The videos circulated before Mongolia announced the donation on Feb 27, 2020.

claim: Volcanic ash can kill the coronavirus.
explaination: WHO says there is no evidence that volcanic ash can destroy COVID-19.

claim: Health Ministry in Ecuador confirms three new cases of coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Pope Francis is infected with coronavirus.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Doctors recommend carbon filter face masks to prevent coronavirus spread.
explaination: Videos falsely claims that doctors are recommending carbon filter masks as a way to protect families, although the FDA and CDC both concluded that they are not effective for children and are not recommended for home use. The videos are used to sell the masks to people concerned about the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Russia announces the closure of airspace and suspends all incoming and outgoing flights to China.
explaination: Russian government had imposed some temporary and partial ban on the movement of Chinese nationals. All Russian airlines, with the exception of national airline Aeroflot (AFLT.MM), stopped flying to China from Jan. 31. Small airline Ikar will also continue flights between Moscow and China. All planes arriving from China will be sent to a separate terminal in the Moscow Sheremetyevo airport. Aeroflot reduced the frequency of flights to Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou until Feb. 29.

claim: Police in China have killed 25,000 COVID-19 patients so far.
explaination: None of the four clips spliced together shows cops “shooting” COVID-19 patients. In fact, one of the clips is actually of a road crash. Another one features not the sound of gunshots, but the explosion of Lunar New Year Fireworks in the background.

claim: COVID-19 came from Chinese people eating human babies, in an effort to improve their skin.
explaination: The netizen’s claim about COVID-19 coming from eating babies is false and baseless. The photos used are also all over a decade old, some of which show a Chinese man "eating babies" as a protest art in 2000.

claim: President Barack Obama “waited six months to call swine flu an emergency after thousands died.”
explaination: The Obama administration declared swine flu, or H1N1, a public health emergency six weeks before H1N1 was declared a pandemic. No H1N1 deaths had yet been recorded in the United States.

claim: The Vatican confirmed that Pope Francis and two aides tested positive for coronavirus.
explaination: The Vatican denied allegations that Pope Francis contracted the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19).

claim: Vitamin helps against COVID-19.
explaination: Health experts told AFP there is insufficient science to definitively say vitamin D can protect from the viral epidemic.

claim: Election years in the United States coincide with major disease outbreaks.
explaination: Several years of discovery or the associated spread of a disease do not match election years, national and international health organizations said.

claim: Shaving facial hair ensures safety from COVID-19, further attributing the message to the CDC.
explaination: Results from our research show that the message from Today.ng's article is a misappropriation of a 2017 NOISH publication; a notification directed at workers using respirators in carrying out their tasks. It has nothing to do with preventing the spread of coronavirus.

claim: Chinese police use a fishing net to arrest a man with a high fever.
explaination: The video shows a police training exercise.

claim: Florida man is arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.
explaination: Image was created using prank generator site.

claim: “Every election year has a disease” — SARS in 2004; avian flu in 2008; swine flu in 2010; MERS in 2012; Ebola in 2014 and 2018; Zika in 2016 and the coronavirus in 2020.
explaination: Most of these diseases were discovered and spread before the election years and were minimally mentioned during campaigns. SARS, avian flu and MERS had virtually no effect on the U.S. during election years.

claim: Airport in Karachi suspends all international arrivals during coronavirus epidemic.
explaination: Pakistan's civil aviation authority confirmed international arrivals weren't cancelled at the time; photo corresponds with one that has circulated about flight suspended at the airport in march 2019

claim: Holding your breath can test for COVID-19.
explaination: WHO and other health experts said there is no evidence to support this claim.

claim: Lysol products can kill the novel coronavirus.
explaination: While Lysol products are advertised to kill 99.9% of bacteria and viruses, including coronavirus, the company is referring to previous strains of the virus. There is no known cure for the novel (or new) coronavirus strain.

claim: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
explaination: WHO hasn't issued advisory against buying of Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China. The viral post is fake.

claim: ”America has been vaccinating cattle for coronavirus for years, yet the news tells you it’s new and going to kill you all, so go buy a mask.”
explaination: The vaccine for cattle won’t help humans, and won't protect against this new form of coronavirus.

claim: “The blood test for coronavirus costs $3,200.”
explaination: The CDC isn't charging for coronavirus testing but patients could be stuck with associated costs, such as a trip to the emergency room. In Florida, a man who worried he was infected initially faced a $3,270 bill even though he never received a coronavirus test.

claim: Starting in March, if you travel outside of the United States you won’t be allowed back in the country “due to high risk of the coronavirus.”
explaination: As of March 6, there is currently no mandate that states Americans are barred from returning to the U.S. from anywhere overseas.

claim: “‘Akira’ is a 1988 movie about an apocalyptic event taking place months before Tokyo 2020 Olympics, showing the WHO advising Japan to postpone the Olympics because of a pandemic risk.”
explaination: The movie does not feature a pandemic of any sort. The WHO is never mentioned in the movie.

claim: CDC issued facial hair recommendation for novel coronavirus prevention.
explaination: Graphic is more than two years old and is unrelated to current outbreak.

claim: You can maintain the alkaline state of the body to avoid contagion.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Hair Weaves And Lace Front Wigs Made In China Likely To Contain coronavirus.
explaination: There is very little chance of coronavirus spreading this way, and there have not been any reported cases of this happening.

claim: A post says “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

claim: “Coronavirus: Florida man arrested for robbery using cough as a weapon.”
explaination: This screenshot of “breaking news” is originally from a satirical news site. If you look closely, you'll see a news generator watermark in the top right corner, meaning the image was created.

claim: The CDC recommends men shave their beards to protect against coronavirus.
explaination: A 2017 CDC infographic shows how facial hair could interfere with respirator masks. The graphic is unrelated to coronavirus protection and the CDC has not recommended people should shave their beards to ward off the virus.

claim: Singapore government said confirmed case No. 12 is a prostitute. As a result, many of her clients are under quarantine.
explaination: According to the Singapore health ministry, case no. 12 showed symptoms during the family trip in Singapore. The department hasn't released the occupation of case no. 12.

claim: A post say “hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
explaination: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

claim: A man is allegedly selling medical masks for 80 denars on a bus owned by the Skopje Public Transportation Enterprise.
explaination: After a short investigation, it was found out that the photo has already been posted on other sites, such as the Facebook page of the site 3minute.net, where the photo was posted on 25 February. According to the status, the photo was taken in the town of Craiova, Romania, and not in Skopje, North Macedonia.

claim: “Hair weave and lace fronts manufactured in China may contain the coronavirus.”
explaination: The Food and Drug Administration has found no evidence that the virus is spreading via imports.

claim: Multiple allegations on how to protect oneself from the new coronavirus.
explaination: Many of the practices detailed in the post are misleading and inaccurate.

claim: Coronavirus infects chickens in Pakistan.
explaination: Authorities say it's related to another disease.

claim: Infected taxi driver demands money from his government otherwise he’ll infect others.
explaination: Story originated from a parody account, no driver is threatneing to spread covid-19 across Nigeria.

claim: Indian Government and the WHO advised people not to purchase colors from China for Holi.
explaination: No such advisory was shared by the government or the Ministry.

claim: China needs coronavirus SWAT (special weapons and tactics) police teams to arrest this coronavirus victim.
explaination: Video shows a mock drill by Tongbai police practicing to take down coronavirus infected patients in case they are uncooperative.

claim: Coronavirus is a bioweapon leaked from a Wuhan lab.
explaination: Already disproved similar claims. Scientists in Wuhan insisted no link between virus and labs.

claim: Evidence indicates COVID-19 escaped a Chinese lab that was researching it, causing the outbreak.
explaination: Overall, Mosher’s argument is based on unfounded speculation and scientific inaccuracies. Multiple scientific studies have indicated that the virus has a natural origin, not the result of human engineering.

claim: The mortality rate for the flu is “right around” that of the new coronavirus: “It’s right around 2%.”
explaination: The mortality rate for the flu is considered by most experts to be about 0.1%. Estimates for the mortality rate for coronavirus are currently around 2%, but this number could change depending on how cases are diagnosed.

claim: These are measures that protect from novel coronavirus.
explaination: Health experts refute new misleading claims about coronavirus prevention in Sri Lanka.

claim: Coronavirus case in Uttar Pradesh district, India.
explaination: Authorities denied.

claim: Shoppers in China storm supermarket after coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: The video has circulated in media reports since at least October 2019, two months before the viral outbreak was first reported.

claim: A Chinese SWAT Team takes down a coronavirus suspect
explaination: A mock drill video was shared as China committing atrocities on its patients.

claim: Video says President Donald Trump spawned the “Wuhan super virus outbreak under code name ‘zyphr.’”
explaination: There’s no evidence that President Trump had anything to do with the creation of the coronavirus.

claim: Nostradamus predicted the coronavirus.
explaination: The predictions of Nostradamus are not correctly translated, and even if Nostradamus truly predicted a “plague”, the title of the original article says that it is taking place in a seaside town. The coronavirus originated in the city of Wuhan in China, which is not a seaside town, which can be confirmed by a simple Google search.

claim: A video shows an anti-China protest amid the COVID-19 outbreak in Italy.
explaination: The video show a march in Rome to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the assassination of Valerio Verbano, an Italian left-wing activist murdered in 1980.

claim: There is a case of coronavirus at the School of Architects of Madrid.
explaination: It was an exercise.

claim: Video shows Chinese officials detaining suspected coronavirus cases.
explaination: The video shows a police drill in China during the novel coronavirus epidemic.

claim: This map shows high sulphur dioxide in Wuhan now due to the burning of corpses.
explaination: Those are only forecasts based on past emissions.

claim: Chinese people flee to Vietnam due to COVID-19.
explaination: The video is from november 2019.

claim: These charts show the difference betweem COVID-19, flu and common cold.
explaination: Charts include inaccurate information about symptoms. They claim people suffering from the novel coronavirus do not develop some symptoms seen in flu or common cold patients, such as a runny or stuffy nose, a sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea and muscle pain, among others -- most of which can actually be seen among COVID-19 patients as well.

claim: Chinese people are fleeing China to Vietnam because of coronavirus.
explaination: People are actually going from Vietnam to China for work.

claim: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.
explaination: No cases were confirmed there, and claim came from non-credible websites.

claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
explaination: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.

claim: Rainbow shimmers behind a COVID-19 disinfectant truck in China.
explaination: It's from March 2019.

claim: Chinese converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVD19 in the country.
explaination: Viral video is available on the internet since June 2019 and has no relation with the current outbreak of coronavirus in China.

claim: The Simpsons predicted the new coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: An image from the show was altered to read “coronavirus”.

claim: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.
explaination: They are queuing for masks.

claim: In Japan, if the new coronavirus test is negative, the cost is 80,000 yen. If positive, the state will bear the cost.
explaination: No voluntary testing of the new coronavirus has been performed. The test is "when it is determined that the prefecture is necessary based on travel history and contact history with patients", but in this case, the test cost is public expense regardless of negative or positive, and it is "free".

claim: Chinese police kill a woman escaping a COVID-19 quarantine in China.
explaination: The scene actually shows a motorbike accident.

claim: Coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon.
explaination: Dr. Francis Boyle did say that coronavirus is a biological warfare weapon, but the story lacks context. There is no supporting evidence to back up that suggestion. It was debunked as a rumor and untrue that coronavirus was made in a lab.

claim: Chinese are converting to Islam after realizing that no Muslim was affected by COVID-19 in the country.
explaination: The viral video is old and not related to coronavirus.

claim: The 2008 book “End of Days” predicted the current coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: Dean Koontz, not Sylvia Browne, wrote about “Wuhan-400”.

claim: A video says “the coronavirus was invented and patented in the USA and then planted in China.”
explaination: There is no evidence the coronavirus was “invented.”

claim: India has developed a treatment for coronavirus.
explaination: The headline of the viral article is misleading. So far, India has not claimed any such discovery.

claim: Studies show the coronavirus was engineered to be a bioweapon.
explaination: The same studies he cites shows how coronavirus strains have an evolutionary, not engineered, relationship.

claim: An Australian couple ordered wine by drone on a Princess Cruise ship.
explaination: The couple said it was a prank.

claim: Drinking alcohol kills the coronavirus.
explaination: Drinking alcohol does not cure coronavirus, alcohol in sanitizers does have an effect.

claim: Data shows a massive release of sulfur dioxide gas near Wuhan.
explaination: The images in the Twitter posts are not satellite measurements, and a member of NASA said the images did not show significantly increased SO2 measurements. Some other websites cited the images as evidence -- though false -- of bodies being burned due to coronavirus.

claim: Popping bubble wrap exposes people to coronavirus.
explaination: Bubble wrap is not produced by people blowing air into the plastic. Claim originated from a satirical Facebook page that was shut down.

claim: Cocaine kills the coronavirus.
explaination: Post claiming cocaine kills coronavirus is fake.

claim: COVID-19 is the name of the vaccine against the novel coronavirus.
explaination: A blog post claiming that the World Health Organization has announced COVID-19 as a vaccine against the novel coronavirus has a false headline. There is no vaccine yet for the disease.

claim: Video shows quarantined people in a building in Shanghai.
explaination: This video shows tower blocks in Shanghai, not Wuhan – and the clip has been edited to include the audio

claim: Thailand cures COVID-19 with anti-HIV drugs.
explaination: Thai doctors say their treatment helped a coronavirus patient recover, but it was not a ‘cure’.

claim: There is a COVID-19 case in east Indian state.
explaination: Local health authority said that there are no confirmed novel coronavirus patients in the area at the time.

claim: There is a COVID-19 case in Ethiopia.
explaination: No case at this date.

claim: Cuban medicine cures COVID-19.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: A video shows a massive explosion in Wuhan, China, to control the spread of coronavirus.
explaination: Viral video on social media dates back to 2015 when there were giant explosions at the Chinese port of Tianjin. This video is old and has no relation with coronavirus.

claim: Latest research by Chinese scientists said coronavirus will render most male patients infertile.
explaination: The study has not been peer-reviewed. But the study also does not go as far as to say coronavirus will definitely cause infertility in men.

claim: An “official” mask to combat the novel coronavirus was released.
explaination: The mask for sale is the Monata reusable dust pollution mask, which is used for woodworking, house cleaning, gardening, and other outdoor activities.

claim: Black skin is resistant to coronavirus.
explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and experts have already denied it.

claim: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte orders state hospital to accept COVID-19 patients from Wuhan.
explaination: Duterte’s speeches prior to the publication of City News’ false report have made no mention of PGH being used for Chinese patients with COVID-19. Neither have legitimate news media organizations reported on this.

claim: Upon approval from Supreme People’s Court, China will kill 20,000 patients with novel coronavirus.
explaination: There is no such case being tried at the Supreme People’s Court of China. The high court’s record of scheduled hearings on its official website does not show that it was set to decide on such a case on Feb. 7, and neither is there a record of it on the resolved cases tab and press releases.

claim: The map is “based on traces of Wuhan citizens,” between the outbreak of the new coronavirus and the blockade of Wuhan.
explaination: This map is an image showing the routes of passenger aircraft around the world, and it is incorrect to use "maps based on traces of movement"

claim: A large amount of sulfur dioxide was observed in Wuhan because up to 14,000 bodies were incinerated.
explaination: The source of the information is "Windy.com", but even if the body was burned, "Windy.com" does not show real-time sulfur dioxide.

claim: New confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Kolkatta reported by Press Trust of India.
explaination: A clear case of misreporting done by PTI. There are no confirmed coronavirus patients in Kolkata/Confirmed both by the airport authority of Kolkatta and the Traveller

claim: High levels of sulfur dioxide in Wuhan “may be a sign of mass cremations of victims of the coronavirus.”
explaination: The photo shows sulfur dioxide projections. It is not a real-time satellite image.

claim: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses trying to escape a building fire.
explaination: The fire was caused due to electrical wiring failure. This video is not related to COVID-19.

claim: The WHO declared COVID-19 is the abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus in December 2019.
explaination: WHO declared the official name of coronavirus as COVID-19, which stands for coronavirus Disease. It has been falsely claimed to be an abbreviation for China Outbreak Virus In December 19.

claim: A residential building was set on fire in Wuhan to control spread of coronavirus.
explaination: A fire broke out in a different city in China, but officials said the fire had no connection to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: High-rise buildings have become human incinerators to combat the spread of the coronavirus.
explaination: There was no concrete evidence to prove that buildings were being burned to stop coronavirus. The Twitter authority cited in the story was not credible.

claim: Coronavirus was created in a lab in Wuhan.
explaination: No scientific evidence exists to assert that the coronavirus was created in a lab. According to the WHO, “Both Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus.”

claim: Chicken infected from coronavirus found In Bangalore.
explaination: Post claiming chicken infected from coronavirus found in Bangalore is fake. The image is old and is not related to 2019 novel coronavirus.

claim: Boiled ginger can cure COVID-19
explaination: Doctors deny this.

claim: COVID-19 means “China Outbreak Virus.”
explaination: It means coronavirus disease.

claim: A video shows a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown.
explaination: False: The video does not show a family killed by the coronavirus amid China’s multi-city lockdown. The family was reported to have died of carbon monoxide poisoning in Dec 2019.

claim: Weed kills the coronavirus.
explaination: Weed doesn't kill coronavirus. Fake post getting viral.

claim: Chinese government requests the Supreme People’s Court for permission to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the disease
explaination: China has not sought the permission of the country's Supreme People's Court to execute 20,000 coronavirus patients.

claim: Bats responsible for the outbreak of coronavirus originated from the rooftop of a house in Wuhan.
explaination: The viral video is around nine years old and is from Miami, USA.

claim: Using cocaine kills the coronavirus
explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. In fact, there is still no cure for the Covid-19.

claim: Philippines has issued an order mandating a compulsory quarantine for all travelers returning from 23 countries.
explaination: Philippine authorities did not issue this warning after the novel coronavirus outbreak.

claim: In Japan, Okinawa Prefecture Governor Tamaki Denny was seen Kachashi dancing with the mayor of Nanjo City. It was reported that “the governor and the mayor danced while the people were terrified about the new coronavirus infection.”
explaination: It is true that Governor Tamaki danced Kachashi with Mayor Zukeran in January 25. But this is before a cruise ship anchored in Naha.

claim: Police publicly kill a coronavirus-infected woman in China.
explaination: Video on social media is not related to coronavirus. The woman in the viral video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

claim: Coronavirus cases reported in Rome, Georgia.
explaination: The medical facility issued a statement saying there was not a confirmed case.

claim: “THE CHINESE HAVE BEGUN TO USE THEIR HUMAN CORPSE TO PROCESS INTO PRODUCTS SUCH AS CORNED BEEF TO SHIP TO AFRICA. Please share with your contacts. Very important”
explaination: The video might be of Tibet or China’s Sichuan as residents of both these territories perform such rituals. However, we haven’t found the origin of this claim hence we can not emphasize whether or not visuals in this video belong to Sky Burial. But from our findings it is evident that the video is in no way related to the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Chinese elderly couple infected with coronavirus says goodbye while they are in a hospital.
explaination: The elderly couple hospitalized for other conditions such as lung cancer and respiratory failure.

claim: The coronavirus pandemic can be dramatically slowed, or stopped, with the immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.
explaination: Maintaining an adequate intake of vitamin C is important for staying healthy. However, evidence from clinical trials shows that regular vitamin C supplementation does not prevent viral respiratory tract infections such as the common cold, which can be caused by coronaviruses, in the general population. Although some studies have shown a reduced incidence of the common cold in individuals undergoing severe physical stress, such as marathon runners.

claim: COVID-19 is officially found in bats.
explaination: The content of both The Daily Mail and Verter News did not say bats were “officially” the source of the 2019-nCoV, only that they were “likely” to be its source.

claim: Silver Solution used on strains of coronavirus “totally eliminates it. Kills it. Deactivates it.”
explaination: There are no pills or remedies that cure any strain of human coronavirus including COVID-19. In fact, Sellman’s "silver solution," and colloidal silver, can hurt you, and not just your wallet.

claim: COVID-19 is more deadly than Ebola or HIV.
explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be false. The post’s claim that coronavirus is the most deadly disease in history is not correct. Global fatalities for HIV and Ebola are far higher, figures from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show.

claim: The Chinese supreme court OK’d euthanasia for 20,000 people.
explaination: The article was published on a site that has regularly produced hoax reports, and China has made no such announcement.

claim: People in Wuhan are locked inside their houses by the Chinese government.
explaination: The video is of people in wuhan offering their respects to the whistleblower, doctor Li Wenliang.

claim: People are lying on the ground in China because they contracted the coronavirus.
explaination: Video comes from South Africa during a initiation rite in a private school.

claim: “Breaking: UK prepares for full lockdown after hundreds of new cases — Wuhan super virus updates.”
explaination: Only about a dozen coronavirus cases have been confirmed in the United Kingdom.

claim: A Chinese pirate movie called “Coronavirus” is sold in Mexico City.
explaination: The video is actually a 2013 South Korean film called Gamgi.

claim: Coronavirus-infected chicken has been found in Bengaluru, India.
explaination: Viral image of sick chicken is old and not related to coronavirus.

claim: Hong Kong police are misappropriating face masks for personal use.
explaination: Photo circulating since 2018.

claim: Green chiratta can prevent COVID-19.
explaination: No scientific evidence for that.

claim: China officially said the new coronavirus had “confirmed aerosol infection” and that “in short, airborne infections” were spread.
explaination: Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.

claim: Satellite images show high levels of sulphur dioxide above China are possible evidence of mass cremations of people who have died from coronavirus.
explaination: False. The maps are not satellite images, and do not show actual levels of sulphur dioxide. They are simply forecasts based on historical data and weather patterns.

claim: Ecuadorean doctor saves lifes during the Wuhan crisis.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: Special prayer is organized by the Muslim community in China to save people from coronavirus.
explaination: Viral video has got nothing to do with the recent coronavirus outbreak

claim: Garlic water can cure novel coronavirus.
explaination: Garlic is a healthy food that may have some antimicrobial properties. However, there is no evidence from the current outbreak that eating garlic has protected people from the new coronavirus.

claim: A woman infected with the coronavirus was killed by Chinese police.
explaination: The woman in the viral video was taken into custody for violating traffic restrictions in China’s Heilongjiang province.

claim: An Ecuadorian doctor saves lives during the Wuhan crisis.
explaination: Please click the link to read the full article

claim: A coronavirus-infected girl was admitted to Badulla Hospital in Sri Lanka.
explaination: “The girl was tested negative for coronavirus, and she was administered medicines for her ailment and then discharged”.

claim: Ginger ale is an effective cure for the 2019 novel coronavirus.
explaination: The World Health Organization (WHO) said drinking traditional herbal teas is “not specifically recommended as 2019-nCoV remedies as they are not effective to protect yourself and can be even harmful.”

claim: The Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of Immigration (BI) “issued a lookout bulletin” for the “arrest and detention” of a Chinese man who “escaped the quarantine area” of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA).
explaination: The BI clarified in a statement that the story of the foreigner's "escape" from NAIA's quarantine area is a hoax. Further, the DOH did not issue any advisory or bulletin about a foreigner who escaped the NAIA quarantine area.

claim: Lysol disinfectant label says it’s tested against the new coronavirus.
explaination: Covs a a family of viruses.

claim: A video shows people screaming in Wuhan because they feared the coronavirus.
explaination: The video is actually of Wuhan residents whistling and shouting to commemorate Dr. Li Wenliang, the whistleblower of the virus who died on February 7 after getting infected.

claim: Kazakhstanis burned and smashed Chinese restaurants and homes because of the spread of coronavirus in the country.
explaination: The video is real, but the text was misleading. There is no connections between pogroms and coronavirus. It was an ethnic conflict between Kazakhs and Dungans that arose on domestic grounds

claim: Autopsy reveals a Wuhan doctor was murdered in his sickbed.
explaination: The story fabricates a quote and did not offer on-the-record source for its claim. It also came from a website that frequently publishes false information. Other news outlets confirmed Li Wenliang died from the coronavirus.

claim: The new coronavirus “causes sudden death syndrome.”
explaination: There is no evidence that the virus causes sudden death syndrome.

claim: Cannibalism in China has caused the outbreak of a new strain of the coronavirus. A Chinese man is preparing a dead baby for consumption.
explaination: No, this photo shows a piece of performance art created by a Chinese artist in 2000.

claim: Thai department of health published an infographic on how to properly wear face masks.
explaination: MOH denied.

claim: A video shows the cause of COVID-19.
explaination: The video has circulated online since at least July 2011 and actually shows repairs being made to the roof of a bat-infested house in the city of Miami in the United States.

claim: A video shows COVID-19 patients in China.
explaination: It's a school initiation in South Africa.

claim: The Asterix comic books and The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: Coronavirus has been around since the 1960s while the Simpsons picture was edited.

claim: China seeks court approval to kill over 20,000 coronavirus patients to stop the spread of the outbreak.
explaination: This unsubstantiated claim came from a website that published frequently false claims. There is no evidence that China went to courts looking for such approval. Claim was also debunked by several other outlets.

claim: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited a mosque amid the coronavirus outbreak and asked the people of the Muslim community to pray about present crisis.
explaination: Chinese President Xi Jinping’s visit to the mosque is not related to coronavirus as the viral video is almost-four-year-old.

claim: There is a patent for the new coronavirus.
explaination: A post claiming that the Pirbright Institute in the UK applied for a patent for the novel coronavirus outbreak, but uses documents showing a patent from 2015 that the institute holds for avian influenza virus, which is also a coronavirus.

claim: Weed (cannabis) cures coronavirus.
explaination: In the absence of any evidence, the claim is found to be misleading.

claim: China is planning to kill coronavirus patients.
explaination: A hoax website, which has been called out multiple times by various fact-checkers for spreading fake news, has published an article without any source of information to claim that China is planning to kill over 20,000 patients who have been infected by coronavirus.

claim: Sanitizer manufacturer Dettol knew about the new coronavirus before it was reported.
explaination: The label of Dettol mentioning that it kills coronavirus is not the recent strain of coronavirus. They have not tested its products for the recent novel coronavirus. Misleading post is getting viral.

claim: China has sought to kill 20,000 coronavirus patients to control the spread of the virus.
explaination: No media outlet has reported it. Also, the claim originates from a rather suspicious website.

claim: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang had dinner in Wuhan during the epidemic.
explaination: Photo taken in 2013 in Sichuan.

claim: The Dettol disinfectant label says COVID-19 was tested.
explaination: COv are a family of viruses

claim: China asks for permission to kill 20,000 infected cases.
explaination: The website is renowned to share misinformation. There is no evidence for China asking for the same.

claim: Vitamin C stops or slows novel coronavirus.
explaination: There is, to date, no known cure for coronavirus. Medical professionals and researchers also said there was no conclusive evidence to suggest Vitamin C can treat or prevent coronavirus.

claim: China is seeking court’s approval to kill all who tested positive with coronavirus.
explaination: The official website of the National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China uploaded the daily brief on coronavirus and there was no mention of any such case there

claim: Woman eats bat soup contaminated with coronavirus in China.
explaination: The video was recorded on the island of Palau, Micronesia in 2016.

claim: People infected with coronavirus die in the street while doctors travel through the infection zone.
explaination: Both images belong to different events. The first photo corresponds to a performance in Germany and the second photo portrays two doctors who care for Ebola sufferers in Uganda.

claim: Coronavirus discovered In broiler chicken.
explaination: Unrelated images of ailing chicken shared with the claim that coronavirus has been discovered in broilers chicken. The viral post is fake.

claim: Several posts say that coronavirus deaths are linked to 5G technology.
explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory. People die because they were infected with the virus SARS-CoV-2.

claim: The new coronavirus can be cured with a bowl of garlic water.
explaination: There’s no scientific evidence to support this theory and there is still no cure to the Covid-19 disease.

claim: Boiled garlic water can protect from COVID-19.
explaination: Health experts refute false claims that drinking boiled garlic water cures novel coronavirus.

claim: Tinospira crispa plants can treat COVID-19.
explaination: Philippine health experts dismiss misleading online claim that tinospora crispa plants can treat novel coronavirus.

claim: There is a case of COVID-19 in Alberta, Canada, on 2/5/20.
explaination: Authorities denied it.

claim: A study is linked to coronavirus.
explaination: The study was linked to filoviruses and had the minimal role of Wuhan's virology institute.

claim: Coronavirus has infected broiler chicken.
explaination: We found the above circulated post to be False. There is no such confirmation that broiler chicken has been infected by coronavirus, the source of the disease is yet to found. The images in circulated are old and unrelated.

claim: Cow urine cures coronavirus.
explaination: In our verification, we found several media reports, research reports, and advisories that talk about prevention and cure of the disease but there was no mention of cow urine and dung in these reports hence the claim made by the Hindu Mahasabha president Swami Chakrapani is ‘Misleading’.

claim: 1. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang visited a mosque and seek protection to the country from coronavirus. 2. Chinese president Xi Jinping visited a mosque in China after realizing the fact that only Allah can save China from this epidemic.
explaination: The first video is of former malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi who visited a mosque in China during his visit in 2015. The second video is also an old one, President Xi Jinping paid a visit to the Xincheng Mosque in Yinchuan city, capital of NW China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region on Tuesday, July 19, 2016.

claim: Chinese prime minister visits a mosque following the coronavirus outbreak.
explaination: The man in the viral video is former Malaysian Prime Minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. The video was shot during his visit to China when he visited Beijing’s Nan Xia Po Mosque in July 2015.

claim: Label on disinfectant says the new coronavirus strain is not new.
explaination: The disinfectant can only eliminate other types of coronaviruses that are found on hard and non-porous surfaces. But it does not include the new strain 2019-nCoV

claim: Sri Lanka has eradicated coronavirus.
explaination: One patient recovered but experts said it's not enough to mention eradication.

claim: A photo shows a Japanese medical professional providing aid in Wuhan.
explaination: This photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team travelling to China in 2008.

claim: 300.000 people are infected with the new coronavirus in China.
explaination: Fewer cases according to China.

claim: COVID-19 comes from rhino horns.
explaination: Origin is unknown and rhino horns could not hold any virus.

claim: Face masks can be steamed for reuse.
explaination: Experts warn against it.

claim: The Chinese prime minister visited a mosque to gain protection for coronavirus.
explaination: The video is of the then Malaysian Prime minister in 2015 visiting a mosque in Beijing.

claim: Dettol sanitizer kills coronavirus and the company knew about the existence of the virus before the outbreak in China.
explaination: Dettol kills older strains of coronavirus but has not tested the new strain yet. coronavirus is a family of strains infecting mammals and humans.

claim: Broiler chickens were found to have coronavirus in Mumbai.
explaination: Chickens have not been identified as the source for the coronavirus so far and the attached pictures are not linked to coronavirus.

claim: Pigs mulled in China are blamed for coronavirus.
explaination: The video is from the African swine flu outbreak in China in 2018-19.

claim: “Kochi Prefectural Assembly, who returned from Wuhan, refused the test while it was infected with coronavirus.”
explaination: No coronavirus infection has been confirmed in Kochi Prefecture, and no tests have been carried out.

claim: Prime Minister of China visited a mosque and realized the only protection from coronavirus is to bow before Allah.
explaination: This Video is from an AP archive repository that was uploaded in 2015 showing ex-Malaysian Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi visiting a mosque in China which is falsely being shared as Prime Minister of China visiting a mosque during coronavirus outbreak in the country. Also as per the AP repository this event took place in the year 2004.

claim: There is a confirmed case of coronavirus in the Macarthur Region of Australia.
explaination: This story has not been reported by 7NEWS Sydney news, nor any other news outlets,(7News Sydney confirmed with us).

claim: Video from China shows people fleeing from coronavirus quarantine.
explaination: The video footage is originally from an anti-government protest that was posted in December 2019, well before the coronavirus quarantine began.

claim: Video shows bat infestation under a tiled roof, the source of coronavirus in Hubei, China.
explaination: The viral video is eight-year-old and it is not from China.

claim: A doctor faints during surgery on a coronavirus patient.
explaination: The video was published in the Chinese social media WEIBO and it shows a fainting doctor during an open heart surgery. According to the post, the video was recorded in a hospital of Zhotong in Yunnan, China.

claim: A doctor named Leslie Chow discovered the coronavirus and died after contact with coronavirus patients.
explaination: The portrait in the post corresponds to the American actor Ken Jeong. However, the doctor Lin Wenliang was the first to warn of the risk of coronavirus.

claim: Chickens cause coronavirus.
explaination: There has been no official confirmation of a link between chicken and nCov - and no source for nCov has been found as yet. However, WHO has said that they are looking into animal sources to find the origin but there is no clarity on what the animal is.

claim: Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma gave US$5 million to a Filipino student who developed a vaccine for novel coronavirus.
explaination: No vaccine has been developed to stop the recently discovered virus. There are also no news reports saying Jack Ma made a special separate donation to a Filipino student in China Medical University.

claim: A video shows domesticated and exotic animals being sold in a wet market in Wuhan, China.
explaination: The video currently being spread on social media is a composite of two different clips, one of Langowan Traditional Market and the other of Tomohon Traditional Market, both in Indonesia.

claim: Japan has sent a 1,000-man medical team to Wuhan.
explaination: The image circulating on social media is over 11 years old, taken on May 20, 2008, of a 22-member medical team at Japan’s Narita International Airport before flying to Chengdu city in China, then been hit by an earthquake.

claim: The novel coronavirus “will not spread” in the Philippines due to the country’s high temperature and relatively high humidity.
explaination: In an email response to this claim, the World Health Organization (WHO) told Rappler that 2019-nCoV "has spread to countries with both hot and humid climates, as well as cold and dry."

claim: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.
explaination: Till the time of writing this article, coronavirus had killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.

claim: There is an herbal cure for COVID-19.
explaination: Health experts in Sri Lanka say there is no evidence asafoetida or other herbal medicine can definitively protect people from infection.

claim: A photo shows people infected with coronavirus  lying on the sidewalk in China.
explaination: It was an artistic performance in germany in 2014.

claim: A video shows bats, the main source of the coronavirus, on many roofs in Hubei district.
explaination: The video is an 8 year old video from Miami Florida and is not linked to the coronavirus.

claim: Vitamin C can “stop” the new coronavirus.
explaination: While it’s true that vitamin C can have a marginal effect on warding off a cold, there’s no evidence that it can stop or treat the new coronavirus.

claim: Chlorine dioxide kits sold online under various “MMS” names — Miracle Mineral Solution, Miracle Mineral Supplement, Master Mineral Solution — will cure the coronavirus.
explaination: MMS does not "cure" coronavirus and can be dangerous to your health.
